Notice




Where the City Charter makes a general reference to State law, the City
Attorney's Office will provide copies of the applicable law upon request.



Chapter 1 - Names, Boundaries, Powers, and General Provisions



Section 1.01.  Name and Boundaries.



The City of Minnetonka, is a municipal corporation in Hennepin County,
Minnesota. It has the boundaries existing now or as may be changed in the
future.



Section 1.02.  Powers. 



The city has all powers that may be possible now or in the future for a
Minnesota municipal corporation to exercise. This section grants to the city
every power that the citizens could lawfully give to themselves as a
municipal corporation, including the power to preserve, protect and promote
the health, safety and general welfare of the city. The specific mention of
particular powers in this charter does not limit the general powers conferred
by this section.



Section 1.03.  Charter as Law.



This charter has the effect of law and need not be pleaded or proved in any
case.



Section 1.04.  Other Laws.



The city may exercise a power given to statutory cities unless that power is
specifically prohibited by this charter.



Chapter 2 - Form of Government



Section 2.01.  Form of Government.



The form of government established by this charter is the "council-manager
plan." The council exercises the legislative power of the city and determines
matters of policy. The city manager heads the city's administrative branch
and is responsible to the council for the administration of city business.



Section 2.02.  Boards and Commissions.



There are no separate, independent administrative boards or commissions,
except those required by law or established by the council. The council may
establish boards or commissions and other groups to advise the council
regarding municipal activities, to investigate subjects of interest to the
city, or to perform quasi-judicial functions. Members of such bodies will be
appointed by the mayor, subject to approval by the council.



Section 2.03.  Elective Officers.



Subd. 1. The council is composed of seven council members who are the mayor,
council member at-large seat A, council member at-large seat B, council
member ward 1, council member ward 2, council member ward 3, and council
member ward 4. A council member must be eligible to vote in the State of
Minnesota, be at least 21 years old, be a resident of the city, and have been
a resident of the city for at least 30 days before the election or
appointment to office. A person elected to represent a particular ward must
reside in that ward. The council is the judge of the qualifications and
eligibility of its own members. The council must provide by ordinance the
manner for taking evidence when qualifications or eligibility is contested.



Subd. 2. Each council member, including the mayor, serves for a term of four
years or until a successor is elected and qualifies. All terms start on the
first Monday of January following the date of the officer's election.



Subd. 3. The mayor and the two at-large council members are elected by all
city residents. Each ward council member is elected by the voters residing in
the ward that the council member represents.



Subd. 4. Municipal elections will be held in odd-numbered years. Elections
for the offices of mayor and council members-at-large will be held every four
years starting in 1997. Elections for the offices of ward council members
will be held every four years starting in 1999.

(Amended by Ord. 2019-01, effective April 17, 2019)



Section 2.04. Wards.



The city is divided into four wards corresponding generally to the four
geographic quadrants of the city:



(a)   Ward 1 - Southeast quadrant



(b)   Ward 2 - Northeast quadrant



(c)   Ward 3 - Northwest quadrant



(d)   Ward 4 - Southwest quadrant



The boundaries of the wards are established by ordinance. A ward is composed
of compact and contiguous territory. The population of the wards must be as
equal as practical; the equal number is determined by dividing the city
population by the number of wards. The difference between the ward with the
lowest population and the ward with the highest population can be no greater
than ten percent of the equal number. If a federal census shows that a ward
no longer meets this requirement, the council must change the ward boundaries
to achieve compliance within the time period required by state law. If a ward
boundary change places a ward council member's residence in a different ward,
the council member will continue in office until the next general municipal
election, at which time the office must be filled for the remainder of that
term.



Section 2.05.  Incompatible Offices.



Subd. 1. A council member may not hold another elected public office during
tenure as a council member. Taking the oath of office for an elected public
position constitutes an automatic resignation from any other elected public
office.



Subd. 2. A council member may not be the city manager or hold any other paid
city position, even if the council member has taken a leave of absence from
the paid city position. A former council member may not hold a paid,
appointed city position for one year after termination of the council
member's service. This does not prohibit a council member from being
appointed mayor if that position is vacant.



Subd. 3. A council member may serve on both the city council and the charter
commission, as long as no more than one council member serves on the charter
commission at one time.



Section 2.06.  Vacancies in the Council.



Subd. 1. Death or resignation. A vacancy in a council position automatically
occurs on the date an incumbent dies. A vacancy also automatically occurs
when an incumbent submits a written resignation to the mayor, city manager,
or city clerk, effective on the date specified. If the date is not specified,
the vacancy is created on the date of submittal.  If the date of submittal
is unknown, then the vacancy will occur on the date the official receives the
written resignation.



Subd. 2. Other vacancies. A vacancy in a council position also exists in the
following situations:



a.   failure of an elected person to qualify on or before the date of the
council's second regular meeting in the year after the election;



b.   termination of residency in the city;



c.   except as provided in section 2.04, termination of a ward council
member's residency in the ward from which elected;



d.   conviction of a felony either before or after qualification for
office; or



e.   loss of qualifications for the elective office.



Subd. 3. Procedure to declare vacancy.



a.   The council must on its own motion declare by resolution that a
vacancy exists when a vacancy occurs for a reason other than death or
resignation.

b.   If the council fails to act or is unaware of a vacancy, a resident
who is an eligible voter in the city may submit a written request with
supporting facts to the city clerk, asking the council to declare a vacancy.
A request submitted within 90 days after another request for the same council
position will not be considered under this section. Within 45 days after
receipt of the request, the council must investigate the claim and either
declare that a vacancy exists or that the request lacked adequate evidentiary
support.



Subd. 4. Procedure to fill the vacancy.



a.   A special election is required to fill a vacancy when:

   (1)   The vacancy has been declared, or has automatically occurred,
befoe the first day to file affidavits of candidacy for the next regular
municipal election; and

   (2)   more than two years remain in the unexpired term.

When this subdivision 4.a. applies, the city council must adopt a resolution
to set the date for the special election at the first regular or special
meeting of the city council occurring after the vacancy automatically occurrs
or at the same meeting at which the vacancy is declared. The special election
must be held in accordance with subdivision 5 of section. The person elected
will serve the unexpired term for that office. The city council, at its
option and at the same or a subsequent meeting, may make an interim
appointment of a person to fill the vacancy until a successor is elected at
the special election and qualifies for the office.

b.   If a special election is not required by subdivision 4.b. above, the
council may either appoint an eligible person to serve until expiration of
the position's term or fill the vacancy by special election. Upon notice of
an impending resignation, the council may begin the process of determining
how to fill the vacancy. No later than 60 days after a vacancy automatically
occurs or is declared to exist, the council must appoint an eligible person
to fill the vacancy or schedule a special election to be held in accordance
with subdivision 5 of this section.



If the council does neither, the mayor, or acting mayor if the vacancy is in
the mayor's position, has seven days to appoint an eligible person to fill
the vacancy.



If after 67 days no appointment is made nor an election scheduled, the clerk
must schedule a special election to be held in accordance with subdivision 5
of this section



Subd. 5. Special Election Requirements



a.   Except as provided in subdivison 5.b. below, special elections must
be held at the earliest date possible under state law. The following
provisions apply:

   (1) candidates must file for office no later than four weeks before the
election;

   (2) no primary will be held; and

   (3) the candidate receiving the highest number of votes is elected.

b.   If a special election occurs in the same year as a regular municipal
election, the council may at its option schedule the special election to
occur in conjunction with the regular municipal election rather than at the
earliest possible date under state law. If adequate time exists to conduct a
primary in compliance with state law for the special election, the provisions
of subdivision 5.a. above will not apply, and the special election will be
conducted in the same manner as regular municipal elections.



Subd. 6. [repealed]



Subd. 7. The term of a council member elected at a special election begins as
soon as the person has qualified for office and the city clerk has issued a
certificate of election to the successful candidate in accordance with state
law. The council member serves until the expiration of the position's term.



Subd. 8. [repealed]



Subd. 9.  When the mayor or a council member is unable to serve in the
office or attend council meetings for a 90-day period because of illness, or
because of absence from or refusal to attend council meetings for a 90-day
period, the city council, by resolution, may declare a temporary vacancy in
that office to exist. After a vacancy is declared, the council must appoint a
qualified individual to fill the vacancy for the remainder of the unexpired
term or until the original officeholder is again able to resume duties and
attend council meetings, whichever is earlier. When the original officeholder
is again able to resume duties and attend council meetings, the council must
by resolution remove the temporary officeholder and restore the original
officeholder.



(Amended by Ord. 2019-01, effective April 17, 2019)



Section 2.07.  Mayor.



The mayor is the presiding officer of the council. The mayor:



(a)   votes as a member of the council;



(b)   has the powers and duties conferred on the mayor by this charter,
city ordinances, and state laws;



(c)   is the official head of the city for ceremonial purposes, for
purpose of serving civil process, and for the purpose of martial law; and



(d)   may declare an emergency in accordance with state law.



The council must choose from its members an acting mayor, who holds office at
the pleasure of the council and serves as mayor in the mayor's absence or
disability. The council may also choose from its members an alternate acting
mayor, who holds office at the pleasure of the council and serves as mayor in
the absence or disability of both the mayor and the acting mayor.



Section 2.08.  Officers.



The city's officers are those officials to whom state law or this charter has
granted certain power to act on the city's behalf. The officers include the
council members, the city manager, the city clerk, the city treasurer, and
the city attorney. The council may by ordinance create other official
positions to exercise specified powers on the city's behalf.



Section 2.09.  Salaries.



The council members may by ordinance establish reasonable amounts for their
salaries. No change in salary takes effect until after the next regular
municipal election. The council members may be reimbursed for their
reasonable expenses incurred in connection with city business.



Section 2.10.  Investigation of City Affairs.



The council and officers authorized by the council may investigate the city's
affairs, subpoena witnesses, administer oaths and compel the production of
books and papers. The council must provide for an audit of the city's
accounts at least once a year by the appropriate state department or a
certified public accountant. The council may conduct surveys or studies of
subjects of municipal concern.



Section 2.11.  Interferences with Administration.



Subd. 1. The council cannot interfere with the city manager in appointing
officers and employees in the administrative branch. The council cannot
require the city manager to hire, terminate, or discipline a particular
person. The council may by ordinance establish a merit system in all or part
of the city administration.



Subd. 2. Except for purposes of inquiry, the council must contact and control
the administrative branch solely through the city manager. The council
cannot, publicly or privately, give an order to the city manager's
subordinates. A single member or group of council members less than a
majority cannot give an order to the city manager.



Chapter 3 - Procedure of Council



Section 3.01.  Council Meetings.



The council must meet at the usual time and place for council meetings on the
first Monday after January 1 following a regular city election. At that time,
the newly elected council members will assume their duties. The council will
meet at the times each month established by ordinance or resolution. The
mayor or three other council members may call a special or emergency council
meeting after giving the notice required by law. Meetings of the council are
public, except as otherwise permitted by law. Any person may inspect the
minutes and records of the meetings at reasonable times.



Section 3.02.  Staffing of Council Meetings.



The city clerk is secretary of the council and keeps minutes of council
proceedings. Upon consultation with the city manager, the council may
designate another city employee (except the city manager or a council member)
to act as secretary and may request that certain city employees be present at
council meetings.



Section 3.03.  Rules of Procedure and Quorum.



The council determines its own rules and order of business. A majority of all
members constitutes a quorum for transacting business, but a smaller number
may adjourn. The council may by ordinance provide a means for a minority to
compel the attendance of absent members.



Section 3.04.  Voting Procedure.



Subd. 1. Each council member's vote on motions, resolutions, and ordinances
must be recorded, unless the vote is unanimous.



Subd. 2. Only the number of council members eligible to vote will be counted
when this charter provides a voting requirement, such as "a majority of all
council members." The total number of council members eligible to vote on a
matter does not include vacancies that exist under the provisions of section
2.06 and council members who cannot vote because of a legally recognized
conflict of interest on the matter.



Section 3.05.  Resolutions, Motions.



Subd. 1. Resolutions must be presented in writing.  An adopted resolution
must be signed by the mayor and attested to by the city clerk. An adopted
resolution takes effect immediately or at a later date stated in it.



Subd. 2. The council may conduct business by motion when a resolution or
ordinance is not required.



Section 3.06.  Adoption of Ordinances.



Subd. 1. Unless this charter or state law provides otherwise, legislation
must be enacted by ordinance, and an ordinance must be approved by a majority
of all council members.



Subd. 2. An ordinance must be presented in writing. The enacting clause of an
ordinance is: "The City of Minnetonka ordains:". Except for an emergency
ordinance, an ordinance cannot be adopted at the meeting when it is
introduced, and at least seven days must elapse between introduction and
adoption.



Subd. 3. An ordinance passed by the council must be signed by the mayor or
acting mayor and attested to by the city clerk. The title and a summary of an
ordinance must be published at least once in the official means of
publication with notice that the full ordinance may be seen on the city's
website or at city hall or may be obtained by standard or electronic mail.



Subd. 4. An emergency ordinance and an ordinance that is not subject to
initiative and referendum under Section 5.01 are effective immediately upon
passage or at a later date stated in it. Other ordinances adopted by the
council are effective 30 days after publication of the summary in the
official means of publication or at a later date stated in them. An ordinance
adopted by the voters is effective immediately upon adoption, or at a later
time stated in it.



Section 3.07.  Emergency Ordinances.



An emergency ordinance is an ordinance necessary for the immediate
preservation of the public peace, health, safety or welfare. It must be
adopted by the affirmative votes of at least five council members and contain
a preamble that defines and declares the emergency. The city may not
prosecute a violation of an emergency ordinance until 24 hours after the
ordinance was either (a) filed with the city clerk and posted in three
conspicuous places in the city or (b) published at least once in the official
means of publication, unless the person charged had actual notice of the
ordinance adoption before the alleged violation. An emergency ordinance is
automatically repealed on the 61st day after adoption, but the ordinance may
be re-enacted if the emergency still exists.



Section 3.08.  Amendment and Repeal of Ordinances.



An ordinance amending or repealing a prior ordinance or part of an ordinance
must state the subject and number of the ordinance or city code section to be
affected. It must set forth in full each section or subdivision to be amended
or repealed.



Section 3.09.  Codification of Ordinances.



Subd. 1. The city clerk must maintain a list by title of all ordinances
adopted by the city. Ordinances of general and permanent application must be
arranged in a code of city ordinances. The ordinance code must be printed and
maintained in a form that allows continuous revision. A code amendment must
be incorporated into to the code as soon as practicable after it is
effective. After each section a note must be placed indicating the
legislative source of the section and any amendments. The city clerk must
have copies of the code available for public distribution free or at a
reasonable charge.



Subd. 2. The council must review the code of ordinances at least every ten
years to ensure that its provisions are current and appropriate. The code may
be re-codified when appropriate. An ordinance provision not previously
published will be effective if it is included in the re-codification and if a
notice is published in the official means of publication for two successive
weeks stating that copies of the code are available at the city clerk's
office.



Subd. 3. Ordinances granting franchises, disposing of public property,
enacting zoning designations of land, and other ordinances that are not of a
general and permanent nature need not be included in the ordinance code. At
the council's discretion, a table of all or some of these ordinances may be
included, or their text may be included as appendices.



Chapter 4 - Nominations and Elections



Section 4.01.  Regular City Elections.



A regular city election must be held on the first Tuesday after the first
Monday in November of odd-numbered years at places designated by the city
council. The city clerk must give notice of the election in the manner
provided by law; however, failure to give notice does not invalidate the
election.



Section 4.02.  Primary Elections.



If one or two candidates file for a particular office, they are declared the
nominees, and no primary will be held. If three or more candidates file for a
particular office, a primary election must be held to determine the nominees
for that office. The primary for that office must be held according to the
schedule for a primary before a state general election, except that it will
be in the year of the city general election. In a primary, the two candidates
receiving the most votes for each office are the sole nominees for that
office at the regular city election.



Section 4.03.  Candidate Filing.



An eligible person may file as a candidate for election by filing their
affidavits of candidacy for a municipal general election with the city clerk
according to the schedule for a state general election, except that it will
be in the year of the city general election. Each position on the council is
a separate office. Each person wishing to be a candidate for a council office
must designate which office is sought. A person may not be a candidate for
more than one council office at an election.



Section 4.04.  Special Elections.



The council may order a special election by resolution. A notice of a special
election must be published in the official means of publication at least
three weeks before the election. The procedure at the election must conform
as closely as possible with that prescribed for other city elections.



Section 4.05.  Election Procedure.



State law will govern all city elections, except as otherwise provided in
this charter or city ordinance.



Section 4.06.  Non-partisan Elections.



Elections for council positions must be held on a nonpartisan basis, with no
party designation on the ballots.



Chapter 5 - Initiative and Referendum



Section 5.01.  General Authority.



The people of the City of Minnetonka reserve to themselves the powers of
initiative and referendum. Initiative is the process for voters to propose
and adopt an ordinance. Referendum is the process to require an ordinance
passed by the council to be referred to the voters for approval or
disapproval. These powers must be exercised in compliance with this charter
and may be exercised only by city residents who are eligible voters under
state law. Initiative and referendum cannot be used with an ordinance that
appropriates money, authorizes the levy of taxes, involves land use or
zoning, or involves the same subject matter as a valid and sufficient
initiative or referendum petition certified to the city council within the
preceding six months.



Section 5.02.  Initiation of Charter Amendments.



Nothing in this charter affects the right of city residents who are eligible
voters to propose amendments to this charter, which is governed by the
Minnesota constitution and statutes.



Section 5.03.  Further Regulations.



The council may further regulate initiative and referendum by ordinance.



Section 5.04.  Commencement of Proceeding.



Five or more Minnetonka city residents who are eligible voters may form a
committee to undertake an initiative or referendum proceeding. The committee
must file an affidavit and its proposed petition with the city clerk before
circulating a petition for signatures. The affidavit must be substantially in
the form attached as Exhibit A-1, must state that a committee has been
formed, must contain the names and addresses of the committee members, and
must be signed by each member of the committee, whose signatures must be
verified by a notary public. For an initiative petition, the affidavit must
also attach a copy of the new ordinance that the committee is proposing. For
a referendum petition, the affidavit must also cite the adopted ordinance
that the committee seeks to reconsider. No petition may be circulated until
the city clerk has approved its form. The city clerk must rule on the
petition's form within five business days after its submittal.



Section 5.05.  Petition.



Subd. 1. General provisions. An initiative or referendum petition must relate
to only one subject which is clearly expressed in the petition. A petition
must be signed only by registered voters of the city, with their residence
address and date of signature. The signatures may be on more than one page.
The circulator of a signature page must be a resident of the city of
Minnetonka who is an eligible voter and must execute an affidavit for each
page, in the form attached as Appendix A-2, verifying that each signature on
the page is genuine.



Subd. 2. Initiative petition. An initiative petition consists of the
signature pages substantially in the form provided in Appendix A-3, each with
the attached text of the proposed ordinance. The number of valid signatures
for an initiative petition must equal at least 10 percent of the number of
persons voting in the city at the last state general election.



Subd. 3. Referendum petition. A referendum petition consists of the signature
pages substantially in the form provided in Appendix A-4, each with the
attached text of the adopted ordinance to be reconsidered. The number of
valid signatures for a referendum petition must equal at least 20 percent of
the number of persons voting in the city at the last state general election.



Section 5.06.  Filing of Petition.



All signature pages must be filed in the city clerks' office as one petition.
A valid referendum petition, including the signature pages, must be submitted
no later than 90 days after the city council adopted the ordinance that is
the subject of the petition.



Section 5.07.  Evaluation and Certification of Petition.



Within 15 working days after the petition is filed, the city clerk must
evaluate the petition for compliance with this chapter. The validity of the
signatures must be judged as of the day the petition was filed. If the city
clerk finds the petition to be sufficient, the clerk must certify the
petition to the council at its next regular meeting, stating the number of
petitioners and the percentage of voters that they constitute. If the city
clerk finds the petition insufficient, the clerk must immediately notify at
least the first three listed members of the sponsoring committee, with the
reasons for the finding. The committee has 30 days in which to correct the
petition. If the clerk finds at the end of the 30 days that the petition is
still insufficient, the clerk must notify at least the first three listed
members of the committee that the petition will not be certified to the city
council. A final finding of insufficiency does not prevent the filing of a
new petition for the same purpose nor prevent the council from referring the
ordinance to the voters at a regular or a special election, at its option.



Section 5.08.  Council Action on Initiative Petition.



Subd. 1. After receiving a certified initiative petition, the council may
refer the proposed ordinance to an appropriate committee. The committee or
council must hold a public hearing on the ordinance. After the public
hearing, but no later than 65 days after the city clerk submitted the
ordinance to the council, the council must take final action on the
ordinance.  If the council passes the proposed ordinance with amendments and
the committee of petitioners has not filed a statement with the city clerk
within 10 days after passage as specified below, the ordinance need not be
submitted to the voters.



Subd. 2. The ordinance proposed in the petition must be submitted to the
voters if:



(a)   the council passes the ordinance with amendments and within 10 days
afterwards at least 3/5 of the members of the petitioners' committee file a
statement with the city clerk expressing dissatisfaction with the council
action; or



(b)   the council fails to pass the ordinance with or without amendments.



Subd. 3. The ordinance must be considered at the next regular municipal or
statewide election, unless there is less than 60 days between that election
and the date that the city council establishes the form of the ballot
question under section 5.10. If there is less than 60 days, the ordinance
will be considered at the following regular municipal or statewide election.
There will be no special election for an initiated ordinance.



Section 5.09.  Council Action on Referendum Petition.



After receiving a certified referendum petition, the council must reconsider
the ordinance at its next regular meeting and either repeal it or reaffirm
the ordinance as passed. In the latter case the council must submit the
ordinance at an election to be held no less than 60 days, but no more than
120 days, after the council establishes the form of the ballot question under
section 5.10. The election must be held at a municipal or statewide election
if one is scheduled in that time period. If one is not scheduled, then the
council must order a special election.. An ordinance does not become
effective if a sufficient referendum petition is filed with the city clerk
before the ordinance's effective date. The ordinance remains suspended
pending an election.



Section 5.10.  Election.



Subd. 1. The city council must hold a public hearing before establishing the
form of the ballot question and must give at least five-days written notice
of the hearing to at least the first three listed members of  the petition
committee. The city council must establish the ballot question within 21 days
after the occurrence of either event in section 5.08, Subd. 2 (a) or (b) for
an initiative proceeding or after the council reaffirms the ordinance under
section 5.09 for a referendum proceeding. The ballot question must state the
substance of the ordinance in an unbiased manner and give the voters the
opportunity to vote either "yes" or "no" on the adoption.



Subd. 2. If a majority of the people voting on an initiated or referred
ordinance are in favor, it becomes a city ordinance, effective immediately
after the vote has been certified or on the date specified in the ordinance,
whichever is later. If less than a majority of the people voting on an
initiated or referred ordinance are in favor, it will not become effective.



Subd. 3. More than one proposed ordinance may be considered at an election,
but the voters must be allowed to vote on each separately. If two initiated
ordinances are approved at one election and are inconsistent, the one
approved by the higher percentage prevails on the inconsistency.



Section 5.11.  Offenses.



It is unlawful for a person to:



(a)   sign a name other than one's own to an initiative or referendum
petition;



(b)   circulate an initiative or referendum petition not in its entirety;



(c)   circulate an initiative or referendum petition when unqualified to
do so; or



(d)   pay or offer to pay a person, or receive payment or agree to receive
payment, on a basis related to the number of signatures obtained for
circulating an initiative or referendum petition. This paragraph does not
prohibit the payment of salary and expenses for circulation of the petition
on a basis not related to the number of signatures obtained.



A violation of this section is a misdemeanor punishable in accordance with
state law.



Section 5.12.  Forms.



Subd. 1. Each affidavit filed by a committee under Section 5.05 must be
substantially in the form attached as Appendix A-1.



Subd. 2. Each affidavit attached to a signature page must be substantially in
the form attached as Appendix A-2.



Subd. 3. Each signature page for an initiative petition must be substantially
in the form attached as Appendix A-3.



Subd. 4. Each signature page for a referendum petition must be substantially
in the form attached as Appendix A-4.



Chapter 6 - City Administration



Section 6.01.  City Manager.



Subd. 1. The city manager is the chief administrative officer of the city.
The city council appoints the city manager, based on training, experience,
and administrative qualifications. The city manager must be a United States
citizen. The council must appoint an acting city manager when the office of
city manager is vacant or when the city manager is suspended, unable to
perform the manager's duties, or otherwise absent for unplanned reasons. The
city manager must designate a qualified person as acting city manager during
a planned absence.



Subd. 2. The city manager is an employee at will, is appointed for an
indefinite term, and may be removed by the council at any time with or
without cause. The city manager may demand written charges and a public
hearing before removal is effective. The city manager must submit the written
demand within 15 days after council action. The public hearing must be held
before the council within 30 days after the city manager's demand. The
council must provide written charges to the city manager at least 10 days
before the hearing. The council may suspend the city manager from office and
appoint an acting city manager before removal takes effect. The city manager
will be paid the city manager's regular salary during suspension pending
removal or after removal and pending the public hearing.



Subd. 3. After the hearing, the council may either reinstate the city manager
or make the removal final. If removed, the city manager has no right to
appeal and no further right to receive the city manager's salary.



Section 6.02.  City Manager's Powers and Duties.



The city manager is responsible for administration of the city's business,
subject to the provisions of this charter and any council regulations. The
city manager has the power and duty to:



a.   ensure that this charter, city ordinances and resolutions are
enforced and implemented;



b.   appoint, suspend, and remove city employees on the basis of merit and
fitness. The appointment and removal of the city attorney and the removal of
department directors is subject to council approval;



c.   adopt and enforce appropriate policies governing employment practices
and employee conduct, including a code of ethics;



d.   manage departments and divisions of the city administration;



e.   attend council meetings with the right to participate in discussions
but not vote. The council may exclude the city manager from a meeting at
which the city manager's removal is considered, to the extent permitted by
law;



f.   recommend to the council measures deemed necessary for the public
welfare and the efficient administration of the city's business;



g.   keep the council fully informed about the city's financial condition
and needs, and prepare and submit the annual budget to the council;



h.   prepare an administrative code or policy manual incorporating the
details of administrative procedure; and



i.   perform other duties prescribed by law, this charter, or the council.



Section 6.03.  Departments.



With council approval, the city manager may create departments, divisions and
other units to administer the city's business and may alter their powers and
organization.



Section 6.04.  Subordinate Officers.



The city clerk and the city treasurer are subordinate to the city manager.
The clerk is responsible for keeping city records. The treasurer is
responsible for managing public funds. They also have other powers and duties
imposed by state law, this charter, and city ordinance.



Section 6.05.  Purchasing.



Subd. 1. The city manager is the city's chief purchasing agent.  The city
manager may make purchases or contracts when the amount does not exceed the
amount at which competitive bids are required by law, unless the city council
adopts an ordinance establishing a limit that is less than the competitive
bidding threshold, but no less than $100,000. In addition, the city manager
may make purchases or contracts exceeding the limit established under this
subdivision if (a) the item is identified in the approved city budget, (b)
the amount is no greater than the budgeted amount, (c) the item is purchased
through a cooperative purchasing agreement with another governmental agency,
and (d) the council is notified of the purchase within a reasonable time.



Subd. 2. The city manager may also make emergency purchases when the
immediate procurement is essential to prevent delays in the work of the city
that may vitally affect the life, health or convenience of the public or the
protection of property.  The city manager must inform the council before
making the emergency purchase, must prepare a full written report of the
circumstances as soon as possible after the emergency purchase, and must
publicly inform the council at the first council meeting after the emergency
purchase. The written report must be available for public inspection.



Subd. 3. Other purchases or contracts may be made only by the council after
receiving the city manager's recommendation.



Section 6.06.  Competitive Contracts.



City contracts must be made in compliance with state law. When sealed bids
are required, the city manager must advertise for bids in the official means
of publication at least one week before the bids are due. The council may
adopt an emergency ordinance waiving this publication requirement. The
specifications for sealed bids must be drafted to prevent fraud and
favoritism but may include reasonable requirements related to legitimate
public concerns. The council may exercise reasonable discretion to award the
contract in the best interests of the city, considering such factors as
price, quality, experience, suitability, availability, compatibility,
efficiency, and overall best value. The council may by ordinance adopt
additional regulations for making city contracts.



Section 6.07.  Document Execution.



Except as otherwise provided in this charter, the mayor and city manager sign
city documents that require approval of the city council, and the city
manager signs city documents that involve matters that are within the city
manager's power. The city manager may delegate the city manager's authority
in writing.



Section 6.08.  Compensation and Recognition.



The city council may approve a comprehensive compensation program for city
employees, including the city manager. The compensation program may include
non-monetary benefits, such as city employee and community volunteer
recognition programs and city employee preventative health and wellness
programs.



Chapter 7 - Taxation and Finances



Section 7.01.  Council Control; Public Purpose Expenditures.



Subd. 1. The council has full authority over the city's financial affairs and
must use sound discretion in exercising this authority. The council must
provide for the collection of revenues and other assets, the auditing and
settlement of accounts, and the safekeeping and disbursement of public funds.



Subd. 2. The city must spend public funds only for public purposes, and the
council may adopt a policy establishing guidelines regarding which
expenditures qualify as having a public purpose consistent with Minnesota law.



Section 7.02.  Fiscal Year.



The city's fiscal year is the calendar year.



Section 7.03.  Taxation.



The council may provide by ordinance for a system of local taxation, to the
extent permitted by state law.



Section 7.04.  Board of Equalization.



Subd. 1. The council is the board of equalization. The council must appoint
two or more non-voting advisors to assist the board in reviewing property
valuations. The advisors must be city residents who are experienced in real
estate matters. Each will serve a one-year term. The council may provide
compensation for the advisors.



Subd. 2. The board's function is to equalize assessments of property for
taxation. The board's actions must be approved by a majority of all its
members. As soon as the board reassesses any property, the city assessor must
notify the property owner of the amount and the reason for the change.



Section 7.05.  Budget Preparation.



The city manager must prepare an annual budget and submit it to the council.
The budget must include a plan for all city funds except those containing
proceeds of bond issues. The budget must show estimated revenues and
expenditures for each fund using generally accepted accounting principles.
Expenditures in the general fund must be shown for each city department or
division. The budget must include comparisons to the actual revenues and
expenditures of the prior two fiscal years. The city manager should submit
explanatory comments with the budget when appropriate.



Section 7.06.  Budget Adoption.



The council must consider the budget in compliance with state law and must
provide a reasonable opportunity for interested citizens to be heard. The
adopted budget must show in detail the city's financial plan for the next
fiscal year. It must show the amounts and sources of revenues and the amounts
and purposes of expenditures. The total expenditures cannot exceed the total
estimated revenues and allocated surplus. The budget must be adopted in
compliance with state law. A majority of the council must adopt the budget by
resolution and must by resolution levy taxes needed to fund budgeted
expenditures. The city clerk will file the tax levy resolution with the
county auditor within the required time period.



Section 7.07.  Budget Enforcement.



Subd. 1. The city manager must enforce the budget. The city manager may
transfer uncommitted funds in the general fund within a department or
division. The city manager may not approve an expenditure unless there are
sufficient funds to pay for it. This is determined by deducting the total
actual and expected expenditures from the actual and expected revenues plus
allocated surplus.



Subd. 2. The city manager may authorize certain employees to make purchases
and to approve claims for payment. An obligation incurred by a city employee
that does not comply with this charter or that exceeds the employee's
authority is the employee's personal obligation, unless ratified by the city
manager or council.



Section 7.08.  Budget Alterations.



The council may not increase the total expenditures in the adopted budget
beyond the amount that actual receipts plus transfers exceed estimated
revenues. The council may reduce an appropriation in the budget by a
resolution adopted by a majority of all members. The council may transfer
uncommitted budget appropriations to other purposes by approval of at least
five members. Council action is not required for transfers made by the city
manager under Section 7.07. The council must adopt by approval of at least
five members a revised budget for the current year when adopting the next
year's budget. The revised budget should incorporate any changes in estimated
revenues and expenditures based on actual revenues and expenditures to that
date. A capital expenditure that exceeds the amount designated in the city
council's adopted capital improvement plan is a budget alteration that
requires five votes.



Section 7.09.  Contingency Amount in Budget.



The council may include a contingency amount in the budget that does not
exceed 10 percent of the total. The council may transfer funds from the
contingency amount to another line item only by approval of at least five
members. The amount transferred may be used only for the purpose designated.



Section 7.10.  Disbursements.



Disbursements of city funds exceeding $100 must be made by an electronic
method or check bearing the actual or facsimile signature of the mayor, city
manager and city treasurer. The city manager must institute safeguards to
ensure that checks and electronic payments are made only by authorized
individuals, for properly authorized public purposes, and in compliance with
this charter. The safeguards must also ensure that disbursements under $100
are approved by personnel authorized by the city manager. For payments other
than employee wages, an accompanying check register or journal entry must
specify the purpose for the disbursement and the fund from which it is
drawn.  All claims for payment must be supported by appropriate
documentation such as an itemized bill, payroll, or time-sheet approved by an
authorized city employee or officer. The council may by ordinance further
regulate the safekeeping and disbursement of city funds.



Section 7.11.  Funds.



The council and city manager must account for the city's finances through a
classification of funds, including a general fund for operating expenses and
other required funds. The council may by ordinance or resolution make
inter-fund loans, except from trust or agency funds or where prohibited by
this charter or law. The council may by ordinance or resolution make
permanent transfers among all funds, except when prohibited by this charter
or law.



Section 7.12.  Accounts and Reports.



The city manager is the city's chief accounting officer. The council may
prescribe and enforce proper accounting methods, forms, periodic reports and
other mechanisms consistent with state law, this charter and city ordinances.
On or before the last day of each June, the city manager must submit to the
council a comprehensive annual financial report of the city's entire
financial operation for the past fiscal year.



Section 7.13.  Debt.



Obligations may not be issued to pay current expenses except as provided in
this charter. The council may issue obligations for any other lawful
municipal purpose. When required by state law, obligations will be issued
only when approved by the majority of registered city voters voting on the
question at an election.



Section 7.14.  Tax Anticipation Certificates.



At any time after January 1, the council may issue certificates of
indebtedness in anticipation of taxes currently levied for a fund but not yet
collected. The total amount of certificates plus interest may not exceed 90
percent of the current taxes that are uncollected at the time of issuance. If
the average percent of city taxes actually collected in the preceding five
years is lower than 90 percent, then this lower percent must be substituted
for the percent in the previous sentence. The certificates must (a) be issued
on conditions determined by the council, (b) bear interest at no more than
the lawful rate, and (c) be payable no later than April 1 of the year
following issuance. The proceeds of the tax levied for the affected fund and
the city's full faith and credit must be irrevocably pledged for redemption
of the certificates in the order of their issuance.



Section 7.15.  Emergency Debt Certificates.



The council may by ordinance issue emergency debt certificates if revenues
become insufficient for ordinary city expenses or if a public emergency
requires extraordinary expenses. These certificates must (a) be on the
conditions that the council determines, (b) not exceed a term of two years,
and (c) bear interest at no more than lawful the rate. The council must levy
a tax sufficient to pay all principal and interest on these certificates. The
ordinance authorizing emergency debt certificates must state the nature of
the emergency and be approved by at least five council members.



Section 7.16.  Equipment Certificates.



The council may issue equipment certificates to purchase fire or police
equipment or street construction or maintenance equipment. These certificates
must be (a) issued on the conditions that the council determines, (b) within
existing debt limits, and (c) payable in not more than five years. The
council must levy a tax for the payment of these certificates in the same
manner as for the payment of bonds.



Section 7.17.  Purchases with Installment Payments.



The council may purchase equipment for street, water, sewer, police, or fire
purposes with conditional sales contracts, if the installment payments do not
extend beyond the estimated useful life of the equipment. The council may
purchase real property through a contract for deed payable over a period not
exceeding five years. The seller's only remedy must be recovery of the
property in case of nonpayment.



Section 7.18.  Community Investment Fund.



Subd. 1. The council must create and maintain a separate fund designated as
the community investment fund. Into this fund are deposited the following:



(a)   surplus money in special assessment accounts that is not needed to
pay the public improvement bonds and that is not transferred to another
improvement fund,



(b)   collections of special assessments received after an improvement
project has been fully funded,



(c)   investment earnings generated by the fund, and



(d)   any other money appropriated by the council or donated to the city
for the fund's purposes.



Subd. 2. The council must by ordinance provide a procedure for expenditures
from the fund. The ordinance must provide that the amount of principal
expended may not exceed the fund's actual investment earnings from the two
calendar years before the expenditure. The ordinance must also provide that
the fund's principal may be expended only if (a) the expenditure is a loan
that must be repaid, or (b) no further expenditures are made from the fund
until the principal has been restored to its previous amount plus 10 percent
of the earnings that would have been generated on the principal at the
previous amount. The council may alter or remove these restrictions on using
principal only by at least six affirmative votes.



Subd. 3. When the city sells an asset that was purchased with money from the
community investment fund, the city's proceeds from the sale must be returned
to the community investment fund, unless money from other city funds was used
to construct, purchase, enlarge, or renovate the asset, in which case the
proceeds must be distributed on an equitable basis.



Chapter 8 - Public Improvements and Special Assessments



Section 8.01.  Powers.



The city may make any type of public improvement not prohibited by law and
may levy special assessments to pay all or part of the costs that are of
local character. Special assessments must be levied according to state law.



Section 8.02.  Current Services.



The council may provide by ordinance that the cost of city services to
streets, sidewalks or other public or private property may be assessed
against the property served and collected in the same manner as special
assessments.



Section 8.03.  Fees and Civil Penalties.



The council may provide by ordinance that fees, civil penalties, and late
payment penalties imposed by the city may be assessed against (a) property
that was the subject matter, or related to the subject matter, of the fees
and penalties, or (b) property that was the location of an activity, proposed
use, city service, or other circumstance that resulted in the fees and
penalties. The ordinance must require the city to attempt to obtain voluntary
payment of the fees and penalties before imposing the assessments. The
ordinance must require the city to give notice and an opportunity to be heard
to the property owner listed on the official tax records before imposing the
assessments. The assessments will be collected like special assessments.



Section 8.04.  Voluntary Assessments for Certain Property Purchases.



After receiving a petition to do so, the council may purchase property in the
city for open space or other public purposes and may recover all or a portion
of the acquisition costs through special assessments against property owned
by the petitioners. The special assessment procedure required by state law
need not be followed in this situation.



Section 8.05.  Construction of Public Improvements.



Construction, maintenance and repair of public improvements may be done with
workers under the city's control or by contract. Contractors must provide to
the city the bonds that are required by state law.



Chapter 9 - Property Acquisition



Section 9.01.  Acquisition of Property.



The city may acquire any kind of property inside or outside of its boundaries
that the city may need for a public purpose. Acquisition may be by purchase,
gift, eminent domain, or other lawful means. The city must follow state law
in acquiring property by eminent domain.



Section 9.02.  Acquisition of Property for Park and Open Space Purposes.



Acquisition of property for park and open space purposes is an authorized
public purpose. "Park purposes" include playground, trail, parkway, open
space, and any other recreational purpose. "Open space" includes land and
water areas retained for use as active or passive recreation areas or for
resource protection.



Chapter 10 - Franchises



Section 10.01.  Franchises Required.



A person or legal entity must obtain a city franchise before installing or
maintaining a fixture in, on, over, or under a city street or public way for
a public utility or other purpose, except when otherwise permitted by law. A
franchise must be granted by an ordinance that is not an emergency ordinance.
The ordinance will contain the franchise conditions. The person or legal
entity obtaining the franchise must pay for publication of the franchise
ordinance and must deposit sufficient funds for that purpose with the city
clerk before ordinance adoption.



Section 10.02.  Public Hearing.



The council must hold a public hearing before a franchise ordinance is
adopted or amended. Notice of the hearing must be published in the official
means of publication at least 10 days before the hearing.



Section 10.03.  Further Regulation; Franchise Value.



The council may by ordinance reasonably regulate and control the exercise of
a franchise, to the extent permitted by law. The value of the franchise may
not be included in the valuation of the grantee's property for any purpose,
including municipal acquisition of the grantee's property by purchase or
eminent domain.



Section 10.04.  Term.



The council may not grant an exclusive or perpetual franchise. If a franchise
is proposed for a term exceeding 20 years, the issue must be submitted to the
voters for approval or disapproval.



Section 10.05.  Renewals.



An extension, renewal or modification of a franchise is subject to the same
limitations and procedures as a new franchise.



Chapter 11 - Public Ownership and Operation of Utilities



Section 11.01.  Acquisition.



The city may own and operate a gas, water, heat, power, light, telephone, or
other public utility for supplying its own needs, those of private consumers,
or both. The city may construct the facilities reasonably needed for the
utility and may acquire existing utility properties. Acquisition of existing
facilities must be by an ordinance that is not an emergency ordinance. The
operation of city-owned public utilities will be under the city manager's
supervision.



Section 11.02.  Rates and Finances.



The council may set just and reasonable fees for municipal utilities and
services. The council should try to make each municipal utility and service
financially self-sustaining. The council must hold a public hearing complying
with section 11.06 before setting utility fees. The council may adopt
regulations governing utility services and establish penalties for violations.



Section 11.03.  Purchase in Bulk.



Instead of the local production of gas, electricity, water and other
utilities, the council may purchase these in bulk and resell them to local
consumers. The council must hold a public hearing complying with section
11.06 before setting the fees.



Section 11.04.  Lease of Plant.



If the public interest will be served, the council may contract with a
private party to operate a city-owned utility for a term not exceeding 10
years. The contract must be contained in an ordinance approved by five
council members. The ordinance may not be an emergency ordinance.



Section 11.05.  Sale of Utility.



A public utility owned by the city may not be sold or otherwise disposed of
unless the full terms of the sale or other disposition are contained in an
ordinance that is submitted to the electorate and approved by a majority of
the voters voting on the issue.



Section 11.06.  Notice of Public Hearings.



Notice of public hearings required by this chapter must be published in the
official means of publication at least 10 days before the hearing. Additional
notice may be given as determined by the council.



Chapter 12 - Miscellaneous and Transition Provisions



Section 12.01.  Official Publications.



The council must annually designate an official means of publication in
accordance with state law. The official means of publication will be used to
publish ordinances and other matters required by law to be published.



Section 12.02.  Oath of Office.



City officers must take an oath of office in substantially the following form
before taking office: "I do solemnly swear (or affirm) to support the
constitutions of the United States and of the State of Minnesota and to
discharge faithfully the duties of (title of position) of the City of
Minnetonka to the best of my judgment and ability."



Section 12.03.  Interest in Contracts; Code of Ethics.



Subd. 1.  A city officer or employee who is authorized to take part in any
manner in a city contract may not voluntarily have a personal financial
interest in the contract, or personally benefit financially from it, except
as permitted by law.



Subd. 2. The council must adopt a code of ethics ordinance governing the
official conduct of all elected and appointed officials. The council may take
whatever reasonable action it deems appropriate after finding that this
ethical code has been violated. The council may also disqualify an official
from voting on a particular matter if the council finds that the official has
a conflict of interest.



Section 12.04.  Official Bonds.



Before assuming their official duties, the city manager, the city clerk, the
city treasurer, and other officers and employees required by ordinance must
each give the city a corporate surety bond securing the proper performance of
official duties and the safekeeping of public funds. The city will pay the
premiums on the bond.



The bond (a) must be in the amount approved by the council, (b) may be either
an individual or blanket surety bond, (c) must be approved as to form by the
city attorney, and (d) must be filed with the city clerk. State laws
governing official bonds must also be satisfied.



Section 12.05.  Sale of Real Property.



Real property of the city may only be disposed of by ordinance. The sale
proceeds must first be used to retire any outstanding indebtedness incurred
by the city in the acquisition or improvement of that property. If there is
no outstanding debt, the council may designate by resolution another public
use for the proceeds.



Section 12.06.  Vacation of Streets, Use of Public Rights-of-Way.



Subd. 1. The council may by resolution vacate all or part of streets, alleys,
public easements, public ways and public grounds.  A vacation may be
approved only if the council determines that it is in the public interest.
The resolution must be adopted by a majority of all council members eligible
to vote.



Subd. 2. The council must hold a public hearing before approving a vacation.
Notice of the hearing must be published in the official means of publication
at least two weeks in advance.  Notice must also be mailed at least 10 days
in advance of the hearing to the owner of each abutting property, and to each
landowner in the plat if the property to be vacated was dedicated as part of
a plat.



Subd. 3. The council may further regulate vacation proceedings by ordinance.
A copy of the vacation resolution will be filed with the appropriate county
officials.



Subd. 4. The council may by ordinance establish a procedure for managing
public rights-of-way that are under the city's jurisdiction. The ordinance
may include a process to permit the private use of a right-of-way that is not
being physically used or occupied by the public, upon such terms and
conditions as the council may provide.



Section 12.07.  Successor Rights and Obligations.



The city succeeds to the property, rights, privileges, and legal obligations
of the Village of Minnetonka.



Section 12.08.  Relationship to State Law.



State laws that are applicable to the City of Minnetonka will supercede any
inconsistent charter provisions. Except as provided by section 1.04, state
laws that are applicable to the City of Minnetonka are supplementary to this
charter.



Section 12.09.  Existing Ordinances Continued.



Ordinances and regulations in force when this charter took effect and
consistent with this charter are continued in full force until amended or
repealed.



Section 12.10.  Human Rights.



City officers and employees will use all city powers to protect citizens from
discriminatory practices in the city based on race, color, creed, religion,
ancestry, national origin or gender.



Section 12.11.  Implementing Ordinances.



The council must adopt regulations by ordinance to implement this charter and
make its provisions effective.



Section 12.12.  Fines and Penalties.



The council may provide by ordinance that a violation of a city ordinance is
either a misdemeanor or a petty misdemeanor, punishable in accordance with
state law. In addition, the council may establish by ordinance a procedure
for imposing a civil penalty not exceeding $2,000 for each ordinance
violation. This procedure must provide an opportunity for a hearing before a
neutral party, which may be the council.



Section 12.13.  Enforcement.



A resident of the city of Minnetonka may bring an action in district court to
enforce a provision in this charter.

Charter History




I.   Adoption



The charter for the City of Minnetonka was adopted by an election held
November 4, 1969.



II.   General Amendments



By Ordinance No. 89-568, adopted October 2, 1989, the charter was revised to
simplify language, eliminate gender-based references, and make style uniform
throughout the charter. Because of the extensive and non-substantive nature
of these general revisions, references to each section affected have not been
included.



By Ordinance No. 2001-20, adopted August 27, 2001, non-substantive changes
were made to the charter to make it more readable and understandable. This
included the re-organization of some chapters into a different structure.
Some sections and subsections of the charter refer to different subject
matter after this ordinance was adopted.
