SECTION 1000.  CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES.



1000.005.  General.



The sales and possession of controlled substances and glue are regulated as
set forth below.



1000.010.  Definitions.



1.   “Controlled substance” means a drug, substance, or immediate
precursor in Schedules I through V of Minn. Stat. § 152.02.  The term does
not include distilled spirits, wine, malt beverages, intoxicating liquors or
tobacco.



2.   “Deliver” means sell, offer for sale, barter, exchange,
administer, dispense, give away, distribute or supply in any other manner. 
The term deliver includes the attempt to do these acts as well as the actual
completed commission.



3.   “Patient” means:



   a.   the individual for whom a controlled substance is prescribed or
to whom a controlled substance is administered; or



   b.   the owner or the agent of the owner of any animal for which a
controlled substance is prescribed or to which a controlled substance is
administered.



4.   “Person” includes every individual, corporation, partnership and
association of one or more individuals.



5.   “Practitioner” means a person licensed by law to prescribe and
administer any of the controlled substances as defined above.



6.   “Pharmacist” means a person licensed and registered with the
Minnesota state board of pharmacy as a registered pharmacist.



7.   “Prescription” means a written or oral order by a practitioner to
a pharmacist for a controlled substance for a particular patient, which
specifies the date of its issue, the name and address of the practitioner,
the name and address of the patient (and, if the controlled substance is
prescribed for an animal, the species of the animal), the name and quantity
of the controlled substance prescribed, the directions for use of the
substance and in the case of a written order, the signature of the
practitioner.  An oral order by a practitioner for a controlled substance
must be promptly reduced to writing by the pharmacist.



8.   “Manufacturer” means a person or persons other than a pharmacist
who prepares controlled substances in dosage forms by mixing, compounding,
encapsulating, entableting, or other process.



9.   “Wholesaler” means a person or persons engaged in the business of
distributing controlled substances to persons included in any of the classes
named in section 1000.020.



10.   “Warehouseman” means a person or persons who stores controlled
substances, for others, and who has no control over the disposition of the
controlled substances except for the purpose of the storage.



1000.015.  Prohibited Acts.



1.   Except as otherwise provided in this section or state law, a person
must not:



   a.   manufacture, sell, offer to sell, give away, barter, deliver,
exchange or distribute; or possess with intent to manufacture, sell, give
away, barter, deliver, exchange or distribute, a controlled substance;



   b.   possess a controlled substance, except when the possession is
for one's own use and is authorized by law; or



   c.   manufacture, sell, transfer, or deliver, attempt or offer to
sell, transfer or deliver a noncontrolled substance in violation of section
1000.025.



2.   A person must not procure, attempt to procure, possess or have
control over a controlled substance by any of the following means:



   a.   fraud, deceit, misrepresentation or subterfuge;



   b.   using a false name, or giving a false address or false credit;



   c.   concealing a material fact;



   d.   forging or altering a prescription;



   e.   making a false statement in any prescription, order, report or
record relative to a controlled substance;



   f.   making, issuing or uttering any false or forged prescription; or



   g.   falsely assuming the title of, or falsely representing any
person to be, a manufacturer, wholesaler, warehouseman, pharmacist,
physician, doctor of osteopathy licensed to practice medicine, dentist,
podiatrist, veterinarian or other authorized person for the purpose of
obtaining a controlled substance



1000.020.  Exceptions.



Section 1000.015 of this ordinance does not apply to the following in the
ordinary course of their trade, business or profession; provided, however,
that this exception is not a defense to the doing of the acts prohibited in
section 1000.015:



1.   practitioners;



2.   pharmacists;



3.   manufacturers;



4.   pharmacists as manufacturers;



5.   wholesalers;



6.   warehousemen;



7.   persons engaged in transporting controlled substances as agent or
employee of a practitioner, pharmacist, manufacturer, warehouseman,
wholesaler, or common carrier;



8.   public officers or public employees in the performance of official
duties requiring possession or control of controlled substances, or persons
aiding these officers or employees in the performance of their duties;



9.   patients who procure, possess, or use a controlled substance in
accordance with terms of a prescription and prescribed treatment;



10.   persons who procure, posses or use controlled substances for the
purpose of lawful research, teaching or testing, and not for sale; and



11.   lawfully licensed and registered hospitals or bona fide institutions
where sick or injured persons are treated, or bona fide hospitals for the
treatment of animals.



1000.025.  Simulated Controlled Substances.



1.   Prohibition.  A person must not knowingly manufacture, sell,
transfer or deliver or attempt to sell, transfer or deliver a noncontrolled
substance upon:



   a.   the express representation that the noncontrolled substance is
a narcotic or nonnarcotic controlled substance;



   b.   the express representation that the substance is of such nature
or appearance that the recipient of the delivery will be able to sell,
transfer or deliver the substance as a controlled substance; or



   c.   under circumstances which would lead a reasonable person to
believe that the substance was a controlled substance.  Any of the following
factors may constitute relevant evidence:



      (1)   the noncontrolled substance was packaged in a manner
normally used for the illegal delivery of controlled substances;



      (2)   the delivery or attempted delivery included an exchange
of or demand for money or other valuable property as consideration for
delivery of the noncontrolled substance, and the amount of the consideration
was substantially in excess of the reasonable value of the noncontrolled
substance; or



      (3)   the physical appearance of the noncontrolled substance
is substantially identical to a specified controlled substance.



2.   Defense not allowed.  In any prosecution under this section, it is
no defense that the accused believed the noncontrolled substance to actually
be a controlled substance.



3.   Exception.  This section does not apply to the prescribing and
dispensing of placebos by licensed practitioners and licensed pharmacists.



1000.030.  Use of Original Containers and Labels Required.



A person who has possession of any controlled substance dispensed by a
pharmacist must keep the controlled substance in the original container in
which it was dispensed by the pharmacist until used in accordance with the
prescription, and must not remove the pharmacist's original label identifying
the prescription from the original container.



1000.035.  Self Service Display Prohibited.



Retail establishments must not sell a toxic substance as defined in Minn.
Stat. § 609.684 from a self-service display.



1000.040.  Confiscation.



Any controlled or noncontrolled substances found in the possession of a
person in violation of this section may be confiscated and forfeited to the
chief of police.



SECTION 1005.  CURFEW.



1005.005.  Findings and Purpose.



1.   In recent years, there has been a significant increase in juvenile
victimization and crime. At the same time, the crimes committed by and
against juveniles have become more violent. A significant percentage of
juvenile crime occurs during curfew hours.



2.   Because of their lack of maturity and experience, juveniles are
particularly susceptible to becoming victims of older perpetrators. The
younger a person is, the more likely he or she is to be a victim of crime.



3.   While parents have the primary responsibility to provide for the
safety and welfare of juveniles, the city of Minnetonka also has a
substantial interest in the safety and welfare of juveniles. Moreover, the
city has an interest in preventing juvenile crime, promoting parental
supervision, and providing for the well being of the general public.



4.   Hennepin county has adopted a county-wide curfew to reduce juvenile
victimization and crime and advance public safety, health, and general
welfare.



5.   The city adopts this ordinance to be consistent with the county-wide
curfew.



1005.010.  Definitions.



1.   “Juvenile” means a person under the age of 18. The term does not
include people under 18 who are married or have been legally emancipated.



2.   “Parent” means birth parents, adoptive parents, and stepparents.



3.   “Guardian” means an adult appointed under Minn. Stat. § 525.6155
or § 525.6165 who has the powers and responsibilities of a parent as defined
by Minn. Stat. § 525.619.



4.   “Responsible adult” means a person 18 years or older specifically
authorized by law or by a parent or guardian to have custody and control of a
juvenile.



5.   “Public place” means any place to which the public or a
substantial group of the public has access and includes streets, highways,
and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office
buildings, transport facilities, and shops.



6.   “Emergency” means a circumstance or combination of circumstances
requiring immediate action to prevent property damage, serious bodily injury
or loss of life.



7.   “Serious bodily injury” means bodily injury that creates a
substantial risk of death or that causes death, serious permanent
disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any body
part or organ.



8.   “Establishment” means any privately-owned place of business to
which the public is invited, including a place of amusement, entertainment,
or refreshment.



9.   “Proprietor” means an individual, firm, association, partnership,
or corporation operating, managing, or conducting an establishment. The term
includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the
officers of a corporation.



1005.015.  Prohibited Acts.



1.   A juvenile under the age of 12 must not be present in a public place
or establishment within the city:



   a.   between 9:00 p.m. on a Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or
Thursday and 5:00 a.m. of the following day; and



   b.   between 10:00 p.m. on a Friday or Saturday and 5:00 a.m. on the
following day.



2.   A juvenile, age 12 through 14, must not be present in a public place
or establishment within the city:



   a.   between 10:00 p.m. on a Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or
Thursday and 5:00 a.m. of the following day; and



   b.   between 11:00 p.m. on a Friday or Saturday and 5:00 a.m. on the
following day.



3.   A juvenile, age 15 through 17, must not be present in a public place
or establishment within the city:



   a.   between 11:00 p.m. on a Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or
Thursday and 5:00 a.m. of the following day; and



   b.   between 12:01 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. on a Saturday or Sunday.



4.   A parent or guardian of a juvenile must not knowingly, or through
negligent supervision, permit the juvenile to be in a public place or
establishment within the city during the hours prohibited in paragraphs 1, 2,
and 3 of this section.



5.   A proprietor of an establishment within the city must not knowingly
permit a juvenile to remain in the establishment or on the establishment's
property during the hours prohibited in paragraphs 1, 2, and 3 of this
section.  If the proprietor is not present at the time of the curfew
violation, the responding officer must leave written notice of the violation
with an employee of the establishment. A copy of the written notice must be
served on the establishment's proprietor personally or by certified mail.



1005.016.    Limitation on Enforcement.



A law enforcement officer may not issue a citation, detain a child or take a
child into custody based on a violation of section 1005.015 (1), (2), or (3)
unless the officer reasonably believes, after speaking with the child and
considering the facts and surrounding circumstances:



   a.   that the child has violated section 1005.015 (1), (2), or (3);
and



   b.   that none of the defenses in section 1005.020 (1) apply.



(Added by Ord. #2006-15, adopted August 7, 2006)



1005.020.  Defenses.



1.   It is an affirmative defense for a juvenile to prove that:



   a.   the juvenile was accompanied by his/her parent, guardian, or
other responsible adult;



   b.   the juvenile was engaged in a lawful employment activity or was
going to or returning home from his/her place of employment;



   c.   the juvenile was involved in an emergency situation;



   d.   the juvenile was going to, attending, or returning home from an
official school, religious, or other recreational activity sponsored and
supervised by a public entity or a civic organization;



   e.   the juvenile was on an errand at the direction of a parent or
guardian;



   f.   the juvenile was exercising First Amendment rights protected by
the United States Constitution or Article I of the Constitution of the state
of Minnesota;



   g.   the juvenile was engaged in interstate travel; or



   h.   the juvenile was on the public right-of-way, boulevard, or
sidewalk abutting the property containing the juvenile’s residence or
abutting the neighboring property, structure, or residence.



2.   It is an affirmative defense for a proprietor of an establishment to
prove that:



   a.   the proprietor or employee reasonably and in good faith relied
upon a juvenile's representations of proof of age. Proof of age may be
established under Minn. Stat. § 340A.503, subd. 6, or other verifiable means
including school identification cards and birth certificates; or



   b.   the proprietor or employee promptly notified the responsible
police agency that a juvenile was present on the premises of the
establishment during curfew hours.



(Amended by Ord. 2012-07, adopted June 25, 2012)



1005.025.  Penalties.



1.   A violation of section 1005.015(1), (2), and (3) will be prosecuted
under Minn. Stat. §260B.235 and will be subject to the penalties provided
there.



2.   A violation of section 1005.015(4) or (5) is a misdemeanor and will
be punishable in accordance with state law.



(Amended by Ord. #2006-15, adopted August 7, 2006)



1005.030.  Preemption.



If this ordinance conflicts with a curfew ordinance adopted by Hennepin
county, the provisions of the Hennepin county ordinance will supersede the
conflicting provisions of this ordinance.



SECTION 1006.  SOCIAL HOSTS.



1006.05.    Findings and Purpose.



1.   The city council finds that:



   a.   Consumption of alcohol by persons under the age of 21 is
harmful to those persons and constitutes a potential threat to public health
from injuries related to alcohol consumption, such as alcohol overdose or
alcohol-related traffic collisions.



   b.   Alcohol is also an addictive drug which, if used irresponsibly,
could have drastic effects on those who use it as well as those who are
affected by the actions of an irresponsible user.



   c.   As a result, gatherings held on private or public property
where alcohol is possessed or consumed by persons under the age of 21 should
be prevented as much as possible.



   d.   Gatherings involving underage possession and consumption often
occur outside the presence of parents or other responsible adults.  However,
there are times when a parent or other adult is present and condones the
activity, and in some circumstances provides the alcohol.



   e.   Although furnishing alcohol to an underage person is a crime,
it is difficult to prove, and an ordinance is necessary to help further
combat underage consumption.



   f.   A deterrent effect will be created by holding a person
criminally responsible for hosting a gathering where underage possession or
consumption occurs.



2.   The purpose of this section is to discourage underage possession and
consumption of alcohol, even if done within the confines of a private
residence, and to hold persons criminally responsible who host gatherings
where persons under 21 years of age possess or consume alcohol, regardless of
whether the person hosting the gathering supplied the alcohol or was present.



3.   The city council intends that this ordinance should not target
parents who may have alcoholic beverages on their premises but who have
issued a standing order that alcohol is not to be consumed by underage
persons on those premises.



1006.010.  Definitions.



For purposes of this section, the following terms have the meanings given:



1.   "Alcohol" means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of
wine, whiskey, rum, brandy, gin, or any other distilled spirits including
dilutions and mixtures thereof from whatever source or by whatever process
produced.



2.   "Alcoholic beverage" means alcohol, spirits, liquor, wine, beer, and
every liquid or solid containing alcohol, spirits, wine, or beer, and which
contains one-half of one percent or more of alcohol by volume and which is
fit for beverage purposes either alone or when diluted, mixed, or combined
with other substances.



3.   "Gathering" means a group of three or more persons who have assembled
or gathered together for a social occasion or other activity.



4.   "Host" means to aid, conduct, sponsor, organize, supervise, control,
or allow a gathering.



5.   "Parent" means a person having the following relationship to a
juvenile:



   a.   a natural parent, adoptive parent, or step-parent;



   b.   a legal guardian; or



   c.   a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of a
court.



6.   "Person" means an individual, partnership, co-partnership,
corporation, or an association of one or more individuals. "Person" does not
include a city, county, or state agency.



7.   "Premises" means any location, including a home, yard, farm, field,
land, apartment, condominium, hotel room, or other dwelling unit, or a hall
or meeting room, park, or any other place of assembly, public or private,
whether occupied on a temporary or permanent basis, whether occupied as a
dwelling or specifically for a party or other social function, and whether
owned, leased, rented, or used with or without permission or compensation.



8.   "Underage person" means an individual under 21 years of age.



1006.015.   Prohibited Acts. 



1.    It is unlawful for a person to host or allow a gathering on any
premises if:



   a.   the person knows that alcohol or alcoholic beverages will be
present; and



   b.   the person knows that an underage person will attend, or is
likely to attend; and



   c.   the person fails to take reasonable steps to prevent the
possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages by an underage person; and



   d.   an underage person consumes an alcoholic beverage, or possesses
an alcoholic beverage with the intent to consume it, at the gathering.



2.    Examples of reasonable steps include:



   a.   directing, on a one-time basis or as a standing order, that no
consumption of alcohol and alcoholic beverages is allowed; or



   b.    controlling access to alcohol and alcoholic beverages; or



   c.   checking identification of attendees to determine age; or



   d.   supervising the activities of underage persons at the gathering
either in person or through a responsible adult.



3.   A person is not criminally responsible under this ordinance if the
person does not know that a gathering will occur, or does not know that
alcoholic beverages will be present, or does not know that an underage person
will be or is likely to be present. However, if a person has the knowledge
specified in paragraph 1 above, a person who hosts a gathering does not have
to be present at the gathering to be criminally responsible.



4.   A person is criminally responsible for violating paragraph 1 above if
the person intentionally aids, advises, hires, counsels, or conspires with or
otherwise procures another to commit the prohibited act.



1006.020.   Exceptions.



1.   This section does not apply to conduct of an underage person that is
permitted by his or her parent and occurs in the parent's household.



2.   This section does not apply to a legally protected religious
observance.



3.   This section does not apply when an underage person is lawfully in
possession of alcohol or alcoholic beverages during the course and scope of
employment.



4.   This section does not apply to the holder of a liquor license issued
under section 600 of this code, but it does apply to a person who hosts a
gathering at such a liquor establishment.



(Added by Ord. 2009-06, adopted May 18, 2009)



SECTION 1010.  CRIMES AFFECTING PUBLIC OFFICERS.



1010.005.  Obstructing an Officer.



A person must not wilfully resist, delay, obstruct, or interfere with a city
officer or employee in discharging or attempting to discharge a lawful duty
of the person’s office.



1010.010.  Disobeying an Officer.



A person must not wilfully fail or refuse to obey a reasonable order of a
firefighter or police officer given in the lawful discharge of duties.



1010.015.  Threatening an Officer.



A person must not directly or indirectly threaten or intimidate a city
officer, city employee, or a person authorized by law to hear or determine a
matter, with intent to induce him/her to act in a particular manner desired
by the person.  A person must not have on his/her person a dangerous weapon
or firearm as defined in section 1025.005 while in the presence of a city
officer or employee who is lawfully performing his/her duties, except that
this provision does not apply to a person who: (a) is showing or transferring
the weapon or firearm to a police officer as part of an investigation; (b) is
lawfully in possession of a weapon or firearm in the scope of his/her
employment duties; or (c) has a lawful permit to carry a weapon.



1010.020.  False Information to Police.



A person must not give any false information, whether written or oral, to a
police officer conducting a lawful police investigation or field inquiry when
the person knew or had reason to know, that the information was false at the
time it was given.



1010.025.  False Information.



A person must not give a false name, address, date of birth, social security
number, or other identifying data to a law enforcement officer lawfully
executing his/her duties, with the intent of misleading the officer as to the
person's identity or residence.



1010.030.  Deer Management Program.



1.   A person must not obstruct or interfere with the city’s deer
management program or threaten, intimidate, obstruct or interfere with an
authorized city employee or agent in implementing the deer management program.



2.   A person must not touch, damage, manipulate, disengage, make
inoperative, or otherwise tamper with a deer trap or other deer removal
equipment or material that is being used as part of the city’s deer
management program.



3.   A person must not be within a deer management area.  A “deer
management area” is a parcel of privately-owned land where a deer trap,
deer removal equipment, or other material being used as a part of the
city’s deer management program is located, or on publicly-owned property,
the area within 100 feet of a deer trap, deer removal equipment, or other
material being used as a part of the city’s deer management program.  If
proven by a preponderance of the evidence, the following are affirmative
defenses to a violation of this section:



   a.   the person was on land which he/she owns or rents;



   b.   the person was lawfully on a public right-of-way;



   c.   the person was in the act of attempting to contact an occupant
of the premises;



   d.   the person was a law enforcement official, firefighter, public
utility employee, or delivery person acting in the normal course of assigned
duties, or a physician, nurse, or other person in the act of providing health
care services to human beings or domestic animals; or



   e.   the person, within ten days of being informed by a police
officer that the person was determined to be within a deer management area,
provided written proof to the officer of permission to be within the deer
management area.  “Permission to be within the deer management area” is
written confirmation from the city or its authorized agent that the person
had the express permission to be in the deer management area, or written
confirmation from the owner or renter of the property that at the time of the
violation the person had the express permission to be there.



   Evidence of any of these affirmative defenses may not be admitted at
trial unless notice is given to the prosecution before the pretrial
hearing.  A person must not provide false proof of permission to be within a
deer management area to a police officer.



4.   A person must not go into or be in an area that the city has closed
to the public as part of the deer management program if the city has provided
notice by conspicuously posted signs or other reasonable means.



1010.035.  Penalty.



A violation of a provisions of this section is a misdemeanor, punishable in
accordance with section 1310.010.



SECTION 1015.  TRESPASS.



1015.005.  Trespass.



1.   A person must not enter or be on the land or premises of another
person, or enter or be within a structure, facility, or enclosure owned by
another person, without legitimate claim of right, in the following
situations:



   a.   when the person refuses to leave upon the oral or written
request of the lawful possessor or the possessor’s agent;



   b.   when the person has been informed orally or in writing by the
lawful possessor or the possessor’s agent that the person is not allowed
upon the land or premises;



   c.   when the structure, facility, or enclosure is locked; or



   d.   when the person's entry is prohibited by conspicuously posted
signs, such as “no trespassing,” “authorized personnel only,” or
“employees only.”



2.   The lawful possessor of land may appoint any Minnetonka police
officer as an agent for the purpose of making a request to leave.



(Amended by Ord. 2012-18, adopted December 3, 2012)



1015.010.  Building Trespass.



A person must not climb upon a building or structure without the express
permission of the person in charge of the building or structure.



1015.015.  Other Acts of Trespass.



A person must not:



1.   permit animals or fowl under his control to go on private property
owned by someone else;



2.   enter on someone else's property with the intent to take or damage
any fruit, vegetable, flower, tree, shrub or other vegetation growing there,
without the consent of the owner or occupant;



3.   go into, be on, or tamper with a motor vehicle, without the
permission of the owner or his/her agent;



4.   deposit or place on someone else's property objects or materials not
requested or permitted by the owner or occupant, such as dirt, tree stumps,
or branches and other debris; or



5.   enter or be on the residential property of another after sunset and
before sunrise.  If proven by a preponderance of the evidence, the following
are affirmative defenses to a violation of this subparagraph:



   a.   the person was in the act of attempting to contact an occupant
of the premises;



   b.   the person was a law enforcement official, firefighter, public
utility employee, or delivery person acting in the normal course of assigned
duties, or a physician, nurse, or other person in the act of providing health
care services to human beings or domestic animals; or



   c.   the person had the consent of an occupant of the premises. 
Consent must be shown by providing, within ten days of being informed by a
police officer that the person was determined to be in violation of this
section, to the officer written proof from an occupant of the premises that
the person had the express or implied permission of that occupant to be on
the property at the time of the violation.



   Evidence of any of these affirmative defenses may not be admitted at
trial unless notice is given to the prosecution before the pretrial
hearing.  A person must not provide false proof of permission to be on
residential property to a police officer.



SECTION 1020.  LURKING, LOITERING, AND PROWLING.



1020.005.  Loitering - Circumstances Cause Alarm.



1.   Prohibition.  A person must not lurk, loiter, or prowl in any place,
at a time or in a manner not usual for law abiding individuals, under
circumstances that warrant alarm for the safety of persons or property in the
vicinity.



2.   Circumstances causing alarm.  Among the circumstances that may be
considered in determining whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the
person takes flight upon the appearance of a police officer, refuses to
identify him/herself or endeavors to conceal him/herself or an object.



3.   Authority to detain.  A police officer may stop and briefly detain a
person suspected of violating paragraph 1 if the person's behavior reasonably
causes suspicion of criminal activity.  The officer's reasonable suspicion
must be based on objective, articulable facts and reasonable inferences drawn
from all the circumstances surrounding the person's behavior.



4.   Opportunity to dispel alarm.  Unless flight by the person or other
circumstances make it impracticable, a police officer must, prior to any
arrest for a violation of paragraph 1, allow the person an opportunity to
dispel any alarm which would otherwise be warranted by requesting him to
identify him/herself and explain his/her presence and conduct.  The person
may identity him/herself by presenting any of the following:



   a.   a state-issued identification card or driver's license
containing the persons' photograph;



   b.   an employer-issued identification card which verifies the
person's employment and includes the person's photograph;



   c.   a currently valid passport;



   d.   a certified copy of the person's birth certificate; or



   e.   verification of the person's identity by another person who can
establish his/her own identity by one of the documents listed above.



   An explanation of the person's presence and conduct will be sufficient
to dispel alarm if it shows that the person was engaging in, and planning to
continue engaging in, lawful activity consistent with his/her actions and all
the circumstances surrounding his/her behavior.



5.   Requisites for conviction.  A person may not be convicted of
violating paragraph 1 if:



   a.   no police officer gave the person the opportunity provided in
subdivision 4 to dispel the alarm created by his/her actions; or



   b.   the finder-of-fact determines that the police officer should
have accepted the person's explanation as sufficient to dispel alarm.



1020.010.  Loitering: Intent to Commit Crime.



A person must not in any public or private place lurk, loiter, prowl, lie in
wait or be concealed with intent to commit any act prohibited by law.



1020.015.  Loitering: Obstructing Public Passage.



A person must not loiter, stand, sit or lie in or upon any public property,
private sidewalk, street, curb, crosswalk, walkway area, parking lot, mall,
or other portion of private property open for public use, so as to
unreasonably block, obstruct, or hinder free passage of the public.  Also, a
person must not unreasonably block, obstruct, or hinder free access to the
entrance of a building or part of a building open to the public without
consent of the owner or occupant.  A person may not be arrested or convicted
under this provision until after a police officer has informed the person
that his/her action violates this ordinance and has asked the person to move
to a location, if one is available, that would not violate this ordinance.



1020.020.  Loitering: Signs Prohibiting.



A person must not loiter, stand, sit or lie for a period longer than 10
minutes in any area where a sign prohibiting loitering has been posted.

(Amended by Ord. #2004-010, adopted April 12, 2004)



1020.025.  Penalty.



A violation of any provision of this section is a misdemeanor, punishable in
accordance with section 1310.010.



SECTION 1025.  DANGEROUS WEAPONS; FIREARMS.



1025.005.  Definitions.



For purposes of this section, the following terms have the meanings given.



1.   “Dangerous weapon” means any of the following objects:



   a.   dagger, dirk or stilleto;



   b.   sabre or sword;



   c.   switchblade knife, spring blade knife or any knife the blade of
which can be opened by gravity, a flick of the wrist, or some type of
mechanism;



   d.   blackjack, sand club, sap, sap gloves, pipe club, bludgeon,
mace club;



   e.   chain club or chains assembled or used as an assault weapon;



   f.   artificial knuckles or other objects designed to be worn over
the fist or knuckles;



   g.   throwing devices with cutting or pointed edges;



   h.   Japanese or other night sticks, nut cracker, nunchaku, chaka,
flail, karate stick, morning star;



   i.   sling shots;



   j.   spears, lances; and



   k.   bow and arrow, blow gun.



2.   “Explosive” means an “explosive device” or incendiary
device” as defined in Minn. Stat. § 299F.72.



3.   “Firearm” means a weapon from which is propelled a missile,
projectile, or bullet by means of explosives, gas or compressed air, springs,
or elastic materials and includes air and “BB” guns.



4.   “Minor” means a person who is less than 18 years old.



5.   “Public place” means an area, building or structure that is open
and accessible to the public.



6.   “Replica firearm” means a device or object that is a facsimile or
toy version of, and reasonably appears to be, a pistol, revolver, shotgun,
sawed-off shotgun, rifle, machine gun, rocket launcher, or any other firearm.



1025.010.  Sale to Minors.



A person must not sell or transfer a dangerous weapon or explosive to a minor
unless the minor's parent or guardian is present at the time of sale or
transfer and gives the person his/her express written consent to the proposed
transaction.



1025.015.  Carrying by Intoxicated Persons or Those Under the Influence of
Controlled Substances.



A person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled
substance must not carry a dangerous weapon or explosive upon his/her person
or in a vehicle.



1025.020.  Possession Prohibited.



1.   Unless permitted by the chief of police, a person must not have a
dangerous weapon or explosive in his/her possession, custody or control in a
public place, in or on private property of another without their permission,
or in a motor vehicle, except in compliance with the following.



   a.   A dangerous weapon or explosive may be transported by a person
directly to or from his/her place of business, the place of purchase, a gun
dealer, a gunsmith, a place of target practice, a gun club, or his/her home.



   b.   A dangerous weapon or explosive may be transported only if it
is:



      (1)   in a closed and fastened container or securely tied
package;



      (2)   in the locked trunk of a vehicle that is used or, if the
vehicle does not have a trunk, in the farthest rear portion of the vehicle in
an area not normally occupied by the driver or passengers; and



      (3)   unloaded, disassembled, or otherwise rendered incapable
of immediate operation, if possible.



2.   The presence of a dangerous weapon or explosive in a passenger
automobile, van, pick-up truck, or sport utility vehicle permits the fact
finder to infer knowing possession of the dangerous weapon or explosive by
the driver or person in control of the vehicle when the weapon or explosive
was in the vehicle.  The inference does not apply:



   a.   to a licensed operator of a vehicle who is at the time
operating it for hire in the lawful and proper pursuit of the operator’s
trade;



   b.   to any person in the vehicle if one of them legally possesses a
dangerous weapon or explosive; or



   c.   when the dangerous weapon or explosive is concealed on the
person of one of the occupants.



3.   A person must not possess, carry, transport, or control a knife or
bladed instrument capable of cutting, stabbing or injuring while on school
property, in a school bus, or on public streets or sidewalks adjacent to a
school.  This prohibition does not apply when knives and bladed instruments
are used as part of an instructional activity carried on in the school, used
in the preparation or consumption of food in a lunchroom or kitchen, or used
as a tool by a person authorized to perform construction, repair or
maintenance services on school property.



1025.025.  Use; Discharge.



1.   A person must not in any public or private place use a dangerous
weapon or explosive or discharge a firearm if the firearm is loaded with
powder, a blank cartridge, explosive, bullet, pellet, or shot, without first
obtaining a permit from the chief of police as set forth in section 1025.030.



2.   The prohibition in paragraph 1 does not apply to:



   a.   licensed peace officers and other personnel authorized by the
chief of police; and



   b.   people lawfully acting in the defense of themselves or others;
and



   c. people engaged in bow fishing on Lake Minnetonka in compliance with
ordinances of the Lake Minnetonka Conservation District and state law.



(Amended by Ord. 2013-13, adopted August 5, 2013)



1025.030.  Permit Application, Granting and Revocation.



1.   Permit issuance. A person may apply to the chief of police for a
permit to possess, use, or transport a dangerous weapon or explosive or to
discharge firearm contrary to the provisions of section 1025.020 and
1025.025.  An application for a permit must be in writing and must state the
reason for requesting the permit, the period for which permit is desired, the
type of dangerous weapon, explosive, or firearm involved, the proposed
activity or use, and any other information that the chief of police deems
useful to review the application.  The chief will issue a permit only if
he/she determines that the proposed use is for a lawful purpose and will be
carried out in a safe manner.  The chief of police may impose conditions to
ensure the lawful and safe use of the permit and may specify the firearm,
explosive, or dangerous weapon to be used and the times, places and
circumstances of use.  Permits are usable only by the person to whom issued.



2.   Ineligible people. A permit under this section may not be issued if
the chief of police determines that the applicant is one of the following
categories of people:



   a.   those listed in Minn. Stat. § 624.713;



   b.   a person who presently has a court restraining order against
him/her, issued because of assaultive, aggressive or threatening behavior;



   c.   a person who is presently on court-ordered probation as the
result of a criminal conviction involving assault or disorderly conduct; or



   d.   a person who has, within the preceding two years, handled
firearms in a negligent, careless, or reckless manner or in a manner that
unreasonably alarms any person.



3.   Permit revocation.



   a.   A permit issued under this section may be revoked if the chief
of police determines that:



      (1)   the terms and conditions of the permit are being or have
been violated;



      (2)   continued use of the permit is or may be a danger to
public safety or any property;



      (3)   the permit holder has used the permit to violate any law
or city ordinance;



      (4)   the permit holder falsified any information or omitted
material information in the application; or



      (5)   the permit holder is or has become one of the persons
listed in subparagraph 2 above.



   b.   The chief of police may revoke the permit by giving written
notice to the permit holder.  The revocation will be effective upon delivery
of the written notice to the address of the permit holder set forth in the
permit application.



   c.   A permit holder aggrieved by a revocation of a permit may
appeal the decision to a court of competent jurisdiction.



   d.   A permit revoked under this ordinance will remain revoked
during the pendency of an appeal.



(Amended by Ord. 2015-19, effective January 29, 2016)



1025.035.  Confiscation.



The chief of police may confiscate and dispose of a dangerous weapon or
explosive worn, carried, possessed, used or handled in violation of any
ordinance or state statute.  The chief of police may provide for its sale,
destruction, or other disposition.



1025.040.  Civil Liability.



Nothing in this section authorizes the use of dangerous weapons, explosives,
and firearms, in a manner that will endanger a human being or property, and
no permit issued relieves a person from civil liability for damage resulting
from use of the permit.



1025.045.  Replica Firearms.



A person must not display, exhibit, brandish, or otherwise employ a replica
firearm in a threatening manner if, in doing so, the person either (1) causes
or attempts to cause fear in another person or (2) acts in reckless disregard
of the risk of causing fear in another person.



1025.050.  Penalty.



A violation of a provision of this section is a misdemeanor, punishable in
accordance with section 1310.010.



SECTION 1030.  PROSTITUTION.



1030.005.  Definitions.



For the purposes of this section the following terms having the meanings
given.



1.   “Prostitute” means an individual who engages in prostitution.



2.   “Prostitution” means engaging or offering or agreeing to engage
for hire or financial remuneration in sexual penetration or sexual contact.



3.   “Sexual penetration” means sexual intercourse, cunnilingus,
fellatio, anal intercourse, or any intrusion however slight into the genital
or anal openings of an individual's body by a part of another individual's
body or an object used for the purpose of satisfying sexual impulses. 
Emission of semen is not necessary.



4.   “Sexual contact” means any of the following acts, if the acts can
reasonably be construed as being for the purpose of satisfying the
individual's sexual impulses:



   a.   the intentional touching by an individual of a prostitute's
intimate body parts; or



   b.   the intentional touching by a prostitute of another
individual's intimate body parts.



1030.010.  Prohibitions.



A person must not:



1.   engage in prostitution;



2.   receive profit, knowing or having reason to know that it is from
prostitution or the promotion of prostitution;



3.   solicit or induce an individual to practice prostitution;



4.   solicit for a prostitute; direct, take or transport another to a
prostitute or bring a prostitute to a person, for the purpose of committing
an act of prostitution; or



5.   hire or offer or agree to hire another person to engage in sexual
penetration or sexual contact.



1030.015.  Penalty.



A violation of a provision of this section is a misdemeanor, punishable in
accordance with section 1310.010.



SECTION 1035.  HUNTING; TRAPPING.



1035.005.  Hunting.



1.   Purpose.  The council of the city of Minnetonka finds that as a
result of the increasing density of population within the city it is contrary
to the general welfare to permit the hunting of game within the city limits.



2.   Hunting prohibited.  A person must not hunt game at any time within
the city limits.



1035.010.  Trapping.



1.   Purpose.  The council of the city of Minnetonka finds it is in the
public interest and for a public purpose to protect wild animals and that
trapping creates a threat to the public health and safety.



2.   Definitions.



   a.   “Trap” means any mechanical device, snare, artificial
light, net, bird line, ferret, hawk, vehicle or contrivance used to trap,
catch, snare, kill or otherwise restrain the free movement of any animal,
wildlife or bird.



   b.   “Trapping” means the setting, laying or otherwise using a
trap to trap, catch, snare, kill or otherwise restrain the free movement of
animals, wildlife or birds.



3.   Trapping prohibited.  Trapping anywhere in the city of Minnetonka is
prohibited.



4.   Exceptions.  The prohibition in paragraph 3 does not apply to:



   a.   people who use a trap on their own private property to prevent
an unsafe condition or the waste or destruction of their property when in
compliance with state law;



   b.   representatives of the city, county or state who may in the
course of their duties be required to use a trap for humane or other
authorized purposes; and



   c.   scientists intending to identify animals, wildlife or birds and
then return them to their natural environment.



1035.015.  Penalty.



A violation of a provision of this section is a misdemeanor, punishable in
accordance with section 1310.010.



SECTION 1040.  HARASSMENT.



1040.005.  Prohibition.



A person must not engage, aid, abet or conspire in any of the following
conduct:



1.   making a telephone call or any other form of electronic communication
which is received by a person or persons within or outside of the city,
whether or not conversation ensues, with the intent to harass, abuse, or
intimidate the recipient of the call or message, or someone known by the
recipient;



2.   mailing, delivering or causing the delivery by any means, including
electronically, of a letter, card, telegram, message, package, or other
tangible material to a person or persons within or outside the city, with the
intent to harass, abuse, or intimidate the recipient of the letter, telegram,
message, package, or other object, or someone known by the recipient;



3.   entering the dwelling or upon the property of another within the city
without claim of right or consent of one who has the right to give consent to
the entry, with the intent to harass, abuse, or intimidate the owner or
occupant of the dwelling or property; or



4.   any conduct, other than that set forth in paragraphs 1 through 3
above, directed toward any person or persons within or outside of the city,
carried out with the intent to harass, abuse, or intimidate the recipient of
the conduct or someone known by the recipient and that has, or is intended to
have, a substantial adverse effect on the safety, security, or privacy of the
recipient or someone known by the recipient.



(Amended by Ord. #2006-09, adopted May 8, 2006)



1040.010.  Definition.



For the purpose of this chapter, conduct carried out with the intent to
harass, abuse, or intimidate means conduct that under the circumstances could
reasonably be expected to cause in another those feelings, as commonly
defined, and that does cause those feelings in the recipient or someone known
by the recipient.



1040.015.  Applicability.



For the purpose of this section, the prohibited conduct may be prosecuted in
the city if the prohibited conduct either occurred, or was directed toward
someone residing, within the city.



(Amended by Ord. #2006-09, adopted May 8, 2006)



1040.020.  Penalty.



A violation of a provision of this section is a misdemeanor, punishable in
accordance with section 1310.010.



SECTION 1045.  MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES.



1045.005.  Disorderly Conduct.



1.   A person must not, in any public or private place, engage in, offer
or threaten to engage in, or congregate because of, any riot, fight, brawl,
tumultuous conduct, act of violence, or any other conduct which disturbs the
peace and quiet of another except for participating in a planned and
organized athletic contest.



2.   A person must not disturb or disrupt a lawful assembly or meeting.



1045.010.  Invasion of Privacy.



A person must not, in any public or private place, with intent to intrude
upon or interfere with the privacy of any individual, enter a toilet or
dressing room designated for the use of the opposite sex or look into any
window or other opening.



(Amended by Ord. 2008-16, adopted May 19, 2008)



1045.015.  Public Indecency.



1.   Purpose. The purpose of this section is to prohibit public indecency
in order to deter criminal activity, to promote societal order and public
health, and to protect children.



2.   Findings. The council makes the following findings regarding the need
to prohibit public indecency:



   a.   Public indecency can increase the incidence of criminal
activity, including prostitution, disorderly conduct and sexual assault;



   b.   Public indecency can expose children to an unhealthy and
nurtureless environment;



   c.   Public indecency can present health concerns in places of
public accommodation and other public settings;



   d.   Public indecency can have a negative impact on the value and
marketability of property; and



   e.   Public indecency can disrupt the orderly operation of public
events and public accommodations, causing societal disorder.



3.   Definitions.  Unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, the
words below are defined for the purpose of this section as follows:



   a.   "Nudity" means:



      1)   the appearance of a human bare buttock, anus, male
genitals, female genitals, pubic area, or the female breast below the top of
the areola; or



      2)   a state of dress that fails to opaquely cover a human
buttock, anus, male genitals, female genitals, or areola of the female breast.



   b.   "Person" means a natural person 12 years of age or older.



   c.   "Public place" means a location frequented by the public, or
where the public is present or likely to be present, or where a person may
reasonably be expected to be observed by members of the public.  Public
place includes streets, sidewalks, parks, beaches, business and commercial
establishments (whether for profit or not-for-profit and whether open to the
public at large or where entrance is limited by a cover charge or membership
requirement), bottle clubs, hotels, motels, restaurants, night clubs, country
clubs, cabarets and meeting facilities utilized by any religious, social,
fraternal or similar organization.



4.    Public indecency prohibited. A person who knowingly or intentionally
in a public place:



   a.   appears in a state of nudity;



   b.   shows his covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state;



   c.   fondles the genitals of himself or herself; or



   d.   fondles the genitals of another person,



   commits public indecency and is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable
under Minnesota law.



5.   Exceptions. Division 4. above does not apply to:



   a.   premises used solely as a private residence whether permanent
or temporary in nature unless a person on or in those premises may reasonably
be expected to be observed by members of the public;



   b.   enclosed motel rooms and hotel rooms designed and intended for
sleeping accommodations if the activity described in division 4. is not
exchanged for money or other consideration;



   c.   doctor's offices, portions of hospitals and similar places in
which nudity or exposure is necessarily and customarily expected outside of
the home and the sphere of privacy constitutionally protected in it;



   d.   a modeling or art class operated by (1) a proprietary school,
licensed by the state; a college, junior college or university supported
entirely or partly by taxation; or (2) a private college or university that
maintains and operates educational programs in which credits are transferable
to a college, junior college or university supported entirely or partly by
taxation or an accredited private college;



   e.   a theatrical production performed in a theater, by a
professional or amateur theatrical or musical company, which has serious
artistic merit; or



   f.   a woman breastfeeding a child.



6.   Limited exception. Division 4.a. above does not apply to enclosed
single sex public restrooms, enclosed single sex functional showers, or
locker and dressing room facilities,



(Amended by Ord. 2012-07, adopted June 25, 2012; Ord. # 2003-24, adopted
September 29, 2003; former section repealed and new section added by Ord.
#2003-05, adopted March 17, 2003)



1045.016. Misuse of Public Restrooms and Changing Areas.



1. Findings.   The council makes the following findings regarding the need
to prohibit the misuse of public restrooms and changing areas:



   a.    Public sexual activity is often preceded by physical or visual
intrusions into a toilet stall.



   b.    Physical or visual intrusions into toilet stalls may be
facilitated by the assumption of unusual positions on fixtures.



   c.    Public sexual activity can offend inadvertent witnesses.



   d.    Public sexual activity can deter the legitimate use of public
spaces.



   e.    Public sexual activity may be related to the spread of
sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV/AIDS.



   f.    Discarded used condoms, lubricant containers, and other
paraphernalia which may be left behind after public sexual activity are
unattractive and potentially hazardous.



   g.    Public sexual activity can attract a hostile audience,
creating a risk of violent crime such as assault and robbery, as well as
nonviolent crime such as blackmail.



   h.    Existing statutes and ordinances which require proof of a
specific intent to invade privacy can be difficult to enforce and do not
adequately address physical or visual intrusions into stalls, which are
legitimate subjects of regulation irrespective of the perpetrator's specific
intent.



   i.    The use of public restroom and changing area fixtures for
purposes other than that for which they are intended poses a risk of damage
to the fixtures.



2. Purpose.   The purpose of this section is to protect the privacy of
persons using public restrooms and changing areas, to deter public indecency,
and to prevent damage to property.



3. Definitions.  Unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, the words
below are defined for the purpose of this section as follows:



   a. "Changing stall" - a partially enclosed and closable area within a
public changing area intended to provide an individual privacy while changing
clothes. "Changing stall" does not include areas within a public changing
area designed for the use of more than one person at a time, or which are
designated by sign as being for the use of families.



   b. "City-owned public restroom or changing area" - a public restroom or
changing area which is located on property either wholly or partially owned
by the city of Minnetonka, or which is located in a facility operated by the
city.



   c. "Person in need of assistance" - a person who because of age,
physical or mental infirmity, or other physical, mental, or emotional
dysfunction, has an impaired ability to provide adequately for the
individual's own care without assistance.



   d. "Public changing area" - an area made available to the public for
the purpose of changing clothes, including changing areas located on either
public or private property.



   e. "Public restroom" - any restroom available to the use of the public,
including restrooms located on either public or private property.  "Public
restroom" also includes a portable toilet enclosure available to the use of
the public.



   f. "Toilet stall" - a partially enclosed and closable area surrounding
a toilet.  "Toilet stall" also includes permanent public restrooms in which
there is one toilet, where there is no separate closable area around the
toilet within the restroom.



4. Intrusion into toilet or changing stall prohibited.  A person who
intentionally, in a public restroom or public changing area:



   a.   places the person's body or any body part into a toilet stall
or changing stall occupied by another;



   b.   is present in a toilet stall, changing stall, or portable
toilet enclosure in which another person is present; or



   c.   looks into a toilet stall or changing stall occupied by
another, commits the offense of intrusion into a toilet or changing stall and
is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable under Minnesota law.



5. Exceptions to prohibition of intrusion into toilet stall or changing stall.



   a.    Subdivision 4 above does not apply to an individual who is
assisting a person in need of assistance in a normal use of a toilet stall or
changing stall.



   b.    Subdivision 4(c) does not apply to an individual who looks
into a toilet stall or changing stall for 2 seconds or less solely for the
purpose of determining whether a stall is occupied.



6.  Misuse of public restroom or changing area fixtures. A person who, in a
public restroom or changing area:



   a.   stands or climbs upon any fixture; or



   b.   sits upon a fixture not intended to be sat upon,



commits the offense of misuse of public restroom or changing area fixtures.



7. Trespass on public restrooms.



   a.    When there is probable cause to believe that a person has
violated Section 1045.16 in a city-owned public restroom or changing area, a
police officer may provide the person a written notice providing that the
person is not to enter any city-owned public restroom or changing area for
one year.



   b.    A person who enters a city-owned public restroom or changing
area within one year after having received a written notice described in
Subdivision 7 (a) commits the offense of trespassing upon a city-owned public
restroom or changing area and is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable under
Minnesota law.



8.  General Exceptions.



   a.    Subdivisions 4 and 6 do not apply to law enforcement officers
engaging in law enforcement duties and emergency medical personnel engaging
in the provision of emergency medical services.



   b.    Subdivisions 4 and 6 do not apply to persons engaged in the
cleaning or maintenance of public restrooms or public changing areas in the
course of their employment.



(Amended by Ord. 2012-07, adopted June 25, 2012; added by Ord. 2008-11,
adopted March 24, 2008)



1045.020.  Sexual Conduct.



A person must not, in a public place, engage in or attempt to engage in
sexual conduct as defined in this section 1145.020. For purposes of this
section, "sexual conduct" means human masturbation, sexual intercourse, or
any touching of the genitals, pubic areas or buttocks of the human male or
female, or the breasts of the female, whether alone or between members of the
same or opposite sex or between humans and animals in an act of apparent
sexual stimulation or gratification.



(Amended by Ord. 2017-05, effective June 3, 2017; Amended by Ord. 2008-12;
adopted March 24, 2008)



1045.025.  Indecent Solicitation.



A person must not, in any public place, solicit or attempt to solict another
to engage in sexual conduct as defined in section 1045.020 or conduct that
involves the touching of the genitals, buttocks or female breast for the
purpose of sexual arousal, gratification, annoyance or offense. This section
is not applicable if the proposed sexual conduct is consensual and is to
occur in a private place and the solicitation does not occur in the presence
of a minor. For purposes of this section, a "public restroom" and a "public
changing area" as defined in city code section 1045.16 are not private places.



(Amended by Ord. 2017-05, effective June 3, 2017; Amended by Ord. #2008-12,
adopted March 24, 2008)



1045.030.  Liquor in Public Places.



A person must not do the following acts within or on a motor vehicle on a
public street or highway, on a parking area open to the public, or on private
property without the written consent of the owner or occupant or oral consent
if the owner or occupant is present:



1.   drink an alcoholic beverage; or



2.   possess on the person, or within immediate reach of the person, an
open or unsealed article which contains an alcoholic beverage.  Location in
the glove compartment is within the immediate reach of people sitting in the
front seat of a motor vehicle.



This prohibition does not apply to park property where the consumption of
alcoholic beverages has been permitted by the city, except that it does apply
within or on a motor vehicle on such park property.



1045.035.  Defacement of Buildings or Places.



A person must not mark with paint or other substance, post handbills on, or
in any other manner deface or damage any building, fence, pole, tree, lawn or
fixture in the city of Minnetonka.



1045.040.  Improper Conduct Affecting Schools.



1.   A person must not disturb or interrupt the peace and order of a
school while in session.



2.   A person must not trespass in or on any school by remaining on the
school premises after being ordered to leave by a school administrator or
teacher.



3.   A person who has been ordered to leave school premises must not
re-enter those premises without the written permission of an authorized
school official.



4.   A person must not loiter on any school ground or in any school
building or structure.



1045.045.  Fraudulent Identification.



A person must not identify him/herself by using a name, address, social
security number, date of birth, or other identifying data that is not his/her
own when applying for credit or returning goods to a business establishment.



1045.050.  Fireworks.



Except as otherwise permitted by state law, a person must not possess, sell,
offer or expose for sale, use, or explode any fireworks as defined in Minn.
Stat. § 624.20.



1045.055.  Tampering with Investigation Scene.



A person must not enter an area that has been designated by a peace officer
or city code enforcement official as the scene of an official investigation,
unless the person has been given permission by a designating official.  An
area is the scene of an official investigation if a peace officer or city
code enforcement official has posted or installed a prominent notice, tape,
or other device that clearly gives notice to a reasonable person that the
area is under investigation.



1045.056.  Use of City Identity.



Except as authorized by the city manager or the manager's designee, a person
must not use the name, logo, or other identifying mark of the city of
Minnetonka, or of any department, facility, or program of the city, in an
advertisement, correspondence, web page, social media page, or any other
item, in such a manner that the item appears to a reasonable person to be a
publication, act, document, or other item of the city.



(Added by Ord. 2011-05, adopted May 2, 2011)



1045.060.  Penalty.



A violation of a provision of this section is a misdemeanor, punishable in
accordance with section 1310.010.

CHAPTER 11:  STREETS, PARKS,
AND OTHER PUBLIC PROPERTY



Section



   1100.   STREET SPECIFICATIONS.



   1105.   DRIVEWAYS, APPROACHES AND ENTRANCES.



   1110.   STREET NUMBERS.



   1115.   STREET LIGHTING SYSTEMS.



   1120.   RIGHT-OF-WAY MANAGEMENT.



   1125.   PRIVATE USE OF UNDEVELOPED RIGHT OF WAY.



   1130.   SNOW REMOVAL RESTRICTIONS.



   1135.   PARK REGULATIONS.



   1140.   VACATION OF PUBLIC STREETS, EASEMENTS AND GROUNDS.



 



SECTION 1100.  STREET SPECIFICATIONS.



1100.005.  Definitions.



For the purpose of this section the words below are defined as follows.



1.   “City” means the city of Minnetonka.



2.   “Engineer” means the city engineer or agent.



3.   “Specifications” means the designs, standards, requirements, and
directions prepared by the engineer, as accepted by the council.



4.   The term “work” includes materials and labor.



5.   “Subdivider” means owner or developer.



1100.010.  Scope.



The specifications for city street construction by subdividers are on file in
the office of the clerk and apply to the construction of streets in
subdivisions preliminarily approved by the council.



1100.015.  Financial Security.



The subdivider must furnish a letter of credit in an amount equal to one and
one-half times the cost of the work estimated by the engineer. The conditions
and form of the letter of credit are subject to the approval of the city
attorney.



1100.020.  Partial Street Construction.



The subdivider may be permitted to complete only the streets in that portion
of the plat that he/she proposes to first develop and record.



1100.025.  Construction of Streets.



The specifications for city street construction are the minimum city standard
and apply to all streets that are to be offered to the city for ownership and
maintenance.



1100.030.  Inspection.



The city will inspect the construction to ensure compliance with the
specifications. The city’s inspection does not include the stake-out,
establishment of grades or similar work. This engineering must be done by the
subdivider's engineer.



1100.035.  Inspection Fee.



The subdivider must pay to the city an inspection fee in the amount
established in section 710. The cost of extra inspection caused by the
subdivider’s failure to promptly or properly meet the specifications will
be charged to the subdivider.



1100.040.  Partial Maintenance.



When a street has been completed to a point where it is suitable for
snowplowing, the city may commence those operations. Snowplowing does not
constitute acceptance for other maintenance and has no effect upon agreements
between the city and the subdivider.



1100.045.  Final Acceptance.



Final acceptance of streets will occur only after the engineer issues a
certificate of approval.



1100.050.  Variance.



The council may permit a variance from these requirements when there is a
hardship and may enter into an escrow agreement when the subdivider cannot
obtain a letter of credit. A variance may be granted only upon the
affirmative vote of two-thirds of the full council.



SECTION 1105.  DRIVEWAYS, APPROACHES AND ENTRANCES.



1105.005.  Definitions.



Unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, the words and terms below are
defined for the purpose of this section as follows:



1.   “Business driveway approach” means a driveway approach providing
motor vehicle access from the public right-of-way to any property other than
a single family detached dwelling.



2.   “City engineer” means the city engineer or an authorized
representative.



3.   “Corner” means the point of intersection of the lines of two
street curb faces extended.



4.   “Curb cut” means the opening along a street curb line or pavement
edge where vehicles may enter and leave the roadway. Its width includes the
width of the driveway approach and of the curb returns, if any.



5.   “Curb return” means that portion of a curb next to a driveway
approach that includes the radius or curvature or the ramp-type lug on
commercial or industrial type pavements and that connects the driveway
approach to the street curb.



6.   “Driveway” means a paved or otherwise delineated area on private
property for the operation of motor vehicles.



7.   “Driveway approach” means a paved or otherwise delineated area on
the public right-of- way that is between the roadway of a public street and
private property and is intended to provide vehicle access from the public
roadway to private property.



8.   “Driveway turnaround” means a paved or otherwise clearly
delineated area on private property that is part of or connected to a
driveway or driveway approach and is sufficient in size for an automobile or
other vehicle to turn 180 degrees without leaving the paved or delineated
area.



9.   “Frontage” means the lot line bordering a public street.



10.   “Parcel of land” means a lot or contiguous lots or a tract
officially registered under one ownership.



11.   “Resident driveway approach” means a driveway approach providing
motor vehicle access from the public right-of-way to a single family detached
dwelling.



12.   “Three-car garage” means a structure for the storage of motor
vehicles that has doors for the entry of motor vehicles with a total width of
at least 24 feet.



1105.010.  Classification.



Driveway approaches are of two classes: (1) resident driveway approaches; and
(2) business driveway approaches.



1105.015.  Prohibited Construction.



A person must not construct, alter, or extend, or permit or cause to be
constructed, altered or extended a driveway approach that can be used only as
a parking space.



1105.020.  Construction Permit Required.



A person must obtain a permit for a driveway approach as provided below
before cutting, breaking out or removing a curb or making other provisions
for a driveway approach along a street or alley.



1105.025.  Application for Permit.



Any person who wants to construct a driveway approach across public
right-of-way must first apply to the city engineer for a permit. The
application must be in writing on a form provided by the city. The
application must contain information showing the legal description of the
property, the street address of the property, the type of construction, the
width of the proposed driveway approach, the location of the proposed
driveway approach on the lot, a profile of the proposed driveway, driveway
drainage plan, if necessary, and other information as may be required. The
application must be filed by the property owner or by his/her authorized
agent.



1105.030.  Issuance of Permit.



A permit may be issued by the city engineer if he/she determines that the
applicant has complied with the terms of this ordinance and paid the permit
fee. The city engineer may approve the driveway as requested or with
stipulated changes that are reasonably necessary for the public safety and
welfare. The city engineer may refuse to issue a permit when, in the
engineer's judgement, the requested construction would pose an unreasonable
hazard to the public. The applicant may appeal a denial to the city council
by submitting a request. The city council may affirm, reverse or modify the
engineer's decision.



1105.035.  Permit Fees.



1.   The permit fees for construction of driveway approaches is
established in section 710.



2.   If a person does work without a permit when a permit is required by
this ordinance, the permit fee will be doubled, in addition to other
penalties provided.



1105.040.  Revocation of Permit.



A permit may be revoked by the city council under the procedures in section
700.035.  In addition, the city council has the right to revoke a driveway
permit and to revise, relocate, or close a driveway approach as the result of
street reconstruction, a change in land use, or a major change in the traffic
pattern of an existing land use.



1105.045.  Authority of City Engineer.



1.   The city engineer may establish regulations and specifications for
materials and method of construction for driveway approaches.  A copy of
these regulations and specifications must be kept on file with the city
clerk.  Construction of a driveway approach must comply with these
regulations and specifications and with any conditions included in the
permit.  The city engineer may inspect the construction at any time to
determine compliance.  The city engineer may revoke a permit issued under
this section when he/she determines that the construction or activity is not
being performed according to the terms of the permit, the adopted regulations
and specifications, or this ordinance.



2.   Notice of revocation, with a description of the facts supporting the
revocation, must be mailed or delivered to the person named in the permit at
the address listed in the permit.



3.   Work must cease upon receipt of the notice of revocation.



4.   A person whose permit is revoked may appeal to the city council by
filing a written notice with the city clerk within 10 days after the date
that the revocation notice was mailed or delivered.



5.   The appeal will be conducted using the procedure in section
700.035(c) and (d).



1105.050.  Submission of Plans to City Engineer.



Plans submitted to the building inspector that include or involve a driveway
approach must be referred by the building inspector to the city engineer for
his/her approval before a building permit may be issued.



1105.055.  Construction Requirements Generally.



In addition to the regulations and specifications adopted by the city
engineer, the following requirements must be met.



1.   A driveway approach must intersect the street pavement at an angle to
be approved by the city engineer based upon the physical characteristics of
the street and the lot being accessed. The angle should be as close as
reasonably practical, in the judgment of the city engineer, to a right angle
to the tangent of the curve of the street pavement.



2.   A curb return must not extend beyond any property line as projected,
except when consented to in writing by the adjoining property owner.



3.   The top of the driveway approach paving at the curb line must be 1
inches above the flowline of the gutter, must not extend into the gutter
beyond the face of the curb or beyond the gutter line, and must not interfere
with the use of the street for the purpose of travel or maintenance. The
constructed street must not be excavated unless the city engineer has given
written permission.



4.   Driveway culverts must be provided and installed as required by the
city engineer.



5.   Driveways must not be constructed over curb stops, if at all
possible. If there is no other feasible location for the driveway, the curb
stop must be set flush with the final driveway surface, and provided with a
sleeve, as shown on the typical section attached to the permit.



6.   The property owner and contractor must protect the public from injury
or damage during the construction of the driveway approach.  A permit issued
under this ordinance must contain the applicant’s agreement that the city
will not be liable for damage that may arise from the work, and that the
applicant will hold the city harmless for any liability incurred by the city
as a result of the work performed under the permit.



7.   Trees or shrubs must not be placed adjacent to the driveway so as to
unreasonably interfere with the ability to see traffic on the public street.



8.   If a lot has frontage on both the turnaround portion of a cul-de-sac
and the portion leading to the turnaround, the driveway must be connected to
the “lead-in” portion of the street and not the turnaround.



9.   A driveway approach must provide access to a parking area, a
driveway, a door intended and used for the entrance of vehicles, or other
similar facility



1105.060.  Resident Driveways, Approaches, and Turnarounds.



1.   Only one driveway approach will be allowed from a single residential
lot to the same street, except that two driveway approaches to the same
street may be allowed when the lot frontage on that street is at least 110
feet. Lots having frontage on more than one street will be allowed driveway
approaches to each street consistent with the standards in this ordinance.



2.   A residential driveway approach must not exceed 20 feet in width at
the point it intersects with the right-of-way line, except that a driveway
approach that provides access to a three-car garage may have a width no
greater than 30 feet at that point.



3.   The total width of driveway approaches to a single lot from a single
street must not exceed 35 feet.



4.   A curb cut must not exceed the width of the driveway approach at the
property line by more than 10 feet.



5.   No portion of a driveway approach, except the curb return, may be
constructed within 45 feet of a corner.



6.   The following must be paved with bituminous concrete blacktop or
equivalent paving: (a) the driveway approach and that part of the driveway
between the minimum required building setback line and the street; or (b)
that part of the driveway approach, driveway and turnarounds that drain to
the street, whichever is greater.



7.   If the city's public works director determines that an existing
driveway is causing a maintenance problem on the public street, including the
washing of dirt and gravel into the public street, the city engineer may
require the property owner to pave the portion of the driveway that is
necessary to remove the maintenance problem. Portland cement concrete will
only be allowed outside the public right-of-way. This requirement cannot be
construed to reduce paving otherwise required by performance standards in the
zoning code or required as a condition to the granting of a conditional use
